ProgramName: Master of Education in School Counseling
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English language proficiency. Options include a minimum score of 71 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.0 on the IELTS, 52 on the PTE Academic, 100 on the Duolingo English Test, or successful completion of level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: Applicants for the M.Ed. in Professional Counseling (both Clinical Mental Health Counseling and School Counseling concentrations) must meet the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies and additional program requirements. To be considered for admission, applicants must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution and submit a graduate school application, the application fee, and all transcripts. Applicants must submit the following directly to the program: Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to the applicant’s potential for graduate education and work as a professional counselor. A resume. A statement of purpose (no more than three pages, double-spaced) addressing the applicant’s interest in the counseling profession, personal characteristics that will contribute to being an effective counselor, and any relevant experience. Official scores on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) (verbal, quantitative, and analytical writing). Applicants with at least a 3.00 undergraduate GPA or a master’s degree may request a GRE waiver from the program coordinator.
Department: College of Education
Description: The Professional Counseling Program at MTSU offers two M.Ed. programs: Clinical Mental Health Counseling and School Counseling. Both programs are CACREP-accredited and designed to prepare students for licensure as professional counselors in the state of Tennessee and for national certification. Our mission is to prepare competent, ethically and culturally-aware counselors to work in a variety of settings. We are committed to an inclusive learning environment and value the importance of diversity and advocacy. We seek to foster a professional identity in our students as counselors who will be leaders, advocates and life-long learners. Faculty in the professional counseling program provide a challenging, yet supportive, student-centered environment. In addition to rigorous coursework and an emphasis on professional identity development, students are provided extensive opportunities for clinical skill development, professional development, research, and service. The School Counseling program prepares students to work as school counselors in K-12 school settings.
Accredidation: CACREP-accredited

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Liberal Arts
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests include TOEFL with a minimum score of 71 (iBT) or 525 (PBT), IELTS with a minimum score of 6.0, PTE Academic with a minimum score of 54, or Duolingo English Test with a minimum score of 95.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Arts in Liberal Arts (M.A.L.A.) program is determined by the candidate’s overall academic record, letters of recommendation, and a writing sample submitted to the program director. Applicants must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. For unconditional admission, a student must have a minimum 2.75 undergraduate GPA. Students with a GPA below 2.75 may be admitted conditionally. For admission, a student must also submit to the director of the M.A.L.A. program a writing sample that demonstrates the applicant’s ability to do graduate-level work and arrange to have two letters of recommendation from former professors sent directly to the program director. Applicants must also submit a one-page statement describing their academic interests and reasons for wanting to pursue the M.A.L.A. degree.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Master of Arts in Liberal Arts (M.A.L.A.) degree is an individually designed, interdisciplinary program of study for students whose educational goals are not met by traditional graduate programs. M.A.L.A. students create their own programs of study by drawing on the course offerings of various departments in the College of Liberal Arts and, when appropriate, on the offerings of other colleges of the university. The program is designed for students who desire a broader-based, more flexible curriculum than is available in a traditional master's degree program. It can be especially useful for those whose career or personal interests are interdisciplinary in nature. The program requires 30 semester hours of course work in at least two, but no more than three, fields of study. Students will also be required to complete a thesis (6 semester hours) or a creative project (3 semester hours) in which they will demonstrate their ability to work in an interdisciplinary manner.

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration in Concrete Industry Management
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting an official score from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic, or by completing Level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements:
Admission to the Master of Business Administration program is based on a combination of GMAT/GRE scores and undergraduate GPA. The minimum requirements are one of the following:

1. GMAT score of 500 or higher (or equivalent GRE score) and a minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.75.
2. Admission Index of 1050 or higher (Index = GPA X 200 + GMAT).

Applicants may be admitted with deficiencies. See director for details.

A GMAT waiver may be considered for candidates who meet the following criteria:

1. an advanced degree (e.g., master’s or doctoral degree) from a regionally accredited institution, or
2. five years of significant, progressive, and professional work experience; an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher from a regionally accredited institution; and successful completion of a business statistics course with a grade of C or better from a regionally accredited institution, or
3. a bachelor’s degree in business from an AACSB-accredited institution with an undergraduate GPA of 3.25 or higher, or
4. an undergraduate GPA of 3.5 or higher from a regionally accredited institution.

Students seeking admission to the Concrete Industry Management concentration must present two years of industry work experience.

In some cases, applicants who do not meet these criteria may be recommended for conditional admission.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Concrete Industry Management (CIM) M.B.A. is a specialized business degree that is designed to broaden the graduate’s knowledge of business and management in general and the concrete industry in particular. Courses are delivered on-campus and synchronously online, providing both face-to-face and virtual interaction with faculty and fellow students. Offered through the Jennings A. Jones College of Business, which is accredited by AACSB International, the CIM M.B.A. is a 30-credit hour program requiring a four-year bachelor's degree. Students from various undergraduate backgrounds are considered.
Accredidation: Offered through the Jennings A. Jones College of Business, which is accredited by AACSB International

ProgramName: Master of Science in Health Care Informatics
EnglishScore: Students from non-English speaking countries must also achieve a minimum score of 550 on the paper-based TOEFL or 213 on the computer-based TOEFL or 79 on the Internet-based TOEFL or 6.5 on the IELTS or graduate from a U.S. institution.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Health Care Informatics is designed to prepare students for informatics leadership roles in a variety of health care settings. The curriculum is comprised of 33-credit hours that provides students with knowledge and skills in information systems, health care systems, and leadership. The curriculum has a strong emphasis on project management, systems analysis and design, and decision support. The program is offered completely online, making it attractive to working professionals. Graduates of the program are able to plan, design, implement, and direct health care information systems in a variety of settings. Students will learn the essentials of health care information technology, data analytics and research, legal and ethical issues, leadership and management, clinical decision support, and project management. Coursework is designed to promote critical thinking and problem-solving skills to manage health information and the systems that store, transmit, and analyze that information.
MinimumGreScore: 146 on the Verbal portion and 144 on the Quantitative portion

ProgramName: Master of Arts in International Affairs
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English are required to furnish the University with proof of English proficiency. This can be met by submitting one of the following: TOEFL (525 paper-based or 71 internet-based), IELTS (6.0), PTE (54), Duolingo (100), or ELS (completion of Level 112).
Requirements:
Applicants should submit the following directly to the College of Graduate Studies:
1. an application for admission,
2. official transcripts of all previous college course work,
3. an official score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE),
4. a statement of purpose outlining their career goals and how a master's degree in International Affairs will help attain them,
5. three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with the student's academic background and potential for graduate studies,
6. a resume, and
7. a writing sample, preferably a research paper written for an upper-division undergraduate course.

In addition to the above, applicants must have an undergraduate degree from an accredited university or college with a minimum 2.75 GPA. Students who do not have at least 18 hours of undergraduate credit in one of the following areas—political science, history, geography, economics, or world languages—may be required to complete at least 12 hours of leveling course work determined by the graduate coordinator. The College of Graduate Studies requires a minimum GRE score of 146 on the verbal portion, 140 on the quantitative portion, and 3.5 on the analytical writing portion. These minimums are required for unconditional admission to the program. The International Affairs M.A. program requires all three components of the GRE exam (Verbal, Quantitative, and Analytical Writing). Applicants must complete the entire exam. Test scores more than five years old will not be accepted.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Concentration: ['International Development and Humanitarian Assistance', 'International Security and Peace Studies']
Description: The Master of Arts in International Affairs (M.A.I.A.) is an interdisciplinary program designed for students who desire careers in the public, private, or non-profit sectors with an international orientation. Graduates find jobs as foreign service officers, intelligence analysts, military officers, international civil servants, political risk analysts, international business consultants, policy advocates for non-governmental organizations, and international bankers, among many others. The curriculum blends academic study with policy analysis to equip students with practical knowledge and marketable skills. Students are encouraged to study foreign languages and travel or study abroad during their program. A capstone experience can take the form of an academic thesis or an applied professional project. The M.A.I.A. offers a general track in International Affairs, or one of two specialized concentrations in International Development and Humanitarian Assistance, or in International Security and Peace Studies.

ProgramName: Concentration in International Security and Peace
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-native English speaking countries must submit one of the following to meet the minimum English proficiency requirement for admission to a graduate degree program: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) with a minimum of 525 on the paper-based test (PBT) or 71 on the internet-based test (iBT); International English Language Testing System (IELTS) with a minimum of a 6.0 band score; Pearson Test of English (PTE) with a minimum of 48; Duolingo with a minimum score of 95; or ELS Language Center's Level 112 of the English for Academic Purposes.
Requirements: All application materials must be submitted to the College of Graduate Studies. Applicants should refer to the graduate catalog for details of the admission process. In addition to the application materials required by the College of Graduate Studies, applicants for the M.A. in International Affairs must also submit the following documents: a statement of purpose outlining interest in the program and career goals (1-2 pages, double-spaced); a resume; three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with applicant's academic and/or professional abilities; and a writing sample (10 pages maximum) that demonstrates applicant's academic writing and research abilities.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Master of Arts in International Affairs (MAIA) is a two-year, 36-credit interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for professional and academic careers in the increasingly complex and interconnected world of international affairs. The MAIA program equips students with the essential knowledge, research skills, and practical tools to understand, analyze, and address the multifaceted political, historical, economic, social, and cultural issues that shape our world. Students in the MAIA program will: Learn to critically examine international issues from a variety of disciplinary perspectives, including political science, history, economics, sociology, and cultural studies. Develop strong analytical and research skills through rigorous coursework, culminating in a thesis or a comprehensive exam project. Gain practical experience through internships, study abroad programs, and other experiential learning opportunities. Engage with faculty who are experts in their fields and are committed to mentoring students. Benefit from a small, diverse, and collaborative learning environment.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $10,000 stipend plus a full tuition waiver

ProgramName: Concentration in International Development and Globalization
EnglishScore: International applicants must have a minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based) or 79 (Internet-based) or an IELTS score of 6.5.
Requirements: Applicants should have a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. To be considered for admission, applicants must have an undergraduate grade point average of 3.00 on a 4.00 scale or have received a master's degree. Applicants who do not have a 3.00 GPA must submit a GRE score of 150 verbal and 144 quantitative. In addition, all applicants must submit a 500-word statement of purpose. Three letters of recommendation should be sent directly to the Graduate School. Recommendation forms are available upon request.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Master of Arts degree in International Affairs is designed to meet the academic and professional needs of students interested in all facets of the international arena. It is an interdisciplinary program that draws upon faculty from seven different departments. The program requires 36 hours of course work that includes an interdisciplinary core of 9 hours. Students may choose to specialize in one of two concentrations: International Security and Peace Studies or International Development and Globalization. All students also choose a regional specialization to further deepen their understanding of global politics and cultures. Students in the program may take advantage of the many study abroad opportunities offered by MTSU, and the program encourages students to pursue internships in the public or private sectors. Students complete their degrees by either writing a master’s thesis or sitting for a comprehensive exam.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Actuarial Science
Requirements:
Admission to the M.S. in Actuarial Science is based on a holistic review of each applicant’s file. The graduate program director will evaluate each applicant’s likelihood of success in the program. Applicants should have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. Preference will be given to those with a sufficient background in mathematics, statistics, or a related field with a GPA of 3.0 or better.

Successful completion of two professional actuarial exams from the Society of Actuaries is expected for admission. Admission may be granted with the completion of only one exam. In this case, the student may be required to successfully complete an approved exam prep course or self-study course and pass the corresponding professional exam as part of their degree program. A student who has not passed any professional actuarial exams may be admitted under certain circumstances but would be required to complete two approved exam prep courses and pass the corresponding exams as part of their degree program. In all cases, two exams must be passed before graduating from the program.

International applicants must satisfy the English proficiency requirements.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description:
An actuary is a business professional who uses mathematical and statistical skills to manage financial risks. Actuaries are in high demand and enjoy a top-ranked profession with excellent salaries and a high level of job satisfaction. For more information, please see BeAnActuary.org.

The M.S. in Actuarial Science program at MTSU offers a balance of theory and application with substantial exposure to the real-world usage of actuarial concepts. Students will be well prepared to pass the preliminary professional examinations administered by the major actuarial professional societies in the United States: the Society of Actuaries (SOA) and the Casualty Actuarial Society (CAS). The program is designed to develop the students’ ability to apply mathematical concepts and analytical skills to solve business problems and manage financial risks in insurance companies, consulting firms, government, and in many other capacities.
Accredidation: The M.S. in Actuarial Science program at MTSU has received the distinction of being designated a Center of Actuarial Excellence (CAE) by the Society of Actuaries (SOA), the largest professional organization for actuaries in the world.

ProgramName: Doctor of Education in Assessment, Learning, and Student Success
EnglishScore: International applicants from non-native English speaking countries must demonstrate English proficiency by meeting the minimum score on one of several approved tests, including TOEFL (71 iBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE (54), Duolingo (100), or by completing ELS Level 112. Certain exemptions apply, such as holding a degree from an accredited U.S. institution.
Requirements:
Admission to the Doctor of Education (Ed.D.) in Assessment, Learning, and Student Success is selective and based upon a holistic review of all application materials. Applicants seeking admission to the Ed.D. program in Assessment, Learning, and Student Success must submit the following to the College of Graduate Studies:

1. An application for admission.
2. Official transcripts of all previous college work. Applicants must possess either
    a master’s degree from an accredited institution with a minimum GPA of 3.25 for all graduate work undertaken or
    an undergraduate degree from an accredited institution with a minimum GPA of 3.25 and a minimum combined GRE score of 297 (150 verbal and 147 quantitative) or MAT score of 400.
3. A curriculum vitae or resume.
4. Three letters of recommendation addressing academic qualifications for doctoral study.
5. A statement of purpose (1000-1500 words) describing the applicant's research interests, professional goals, and how the program will advance those goals.
6. A writing sample demonstrating the applicant’s academic writing skills (e.g., master's thesis, course paper, or professional publication).
Department: College of Education
Description: MTSU’s Doctor of Education, or Ed.D., in Assessment, Learning, and Student Success program is designed for those working in K-12 and higher education who are interested in improving teaching and student learning. The program focuses on three major areas: assessment, learning, and student success. It has a focus on improvement science, an approach to problem-solving. Students identify a problem of practice in their context, their school or school district, try to make a change that they think will be an improvement and then study it in very rapid cycles. Graduates of this program are qualified to work as assessment specialists in school districts, universities, and other government agencies or private companies; direct student success initiatives at colleges and universities; teach in higher education institutions; or become curriculum specialists in school districts.
ScholarshipType: Graduate Assistantships, MTSU Graduate Scholarship, Dissertation Scholarships

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit one of the following to demonstrate English proficiency: TOEFL score of 525 (paper-based) or 71 (Internet-based); IELTS score of 6.0; PTE score of 58; Duolingo score of 100; or completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements:
To apply for the M.A. in Economics program, a prospective student must have the following:
1. A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. We welcome applicants with various undergraduate backgrounds.
2. An official Graduate Record Examination (GRE) score. There is no minimum score requirement; however, a quantitative score of 151 or above is recommended. To request a GRE waiver, please contact the graduate program director. The GMAT will also be accepted.
3. Two letters of recommendation.
4. For international students, an official TOEFL or IELTS score is required if the bachelor's degree was not from a US institution.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Master of Arts in Economics is designed to prepare students for careers as professional economists in business and government. It is also an excellent preparation for students who wish to pursue a Ph.D. in economics. The program is small, allowing for close student-faculty interaction. The program may be completed on a full-time (three courses per semester) or part-time basis. Full-time students typically finish the program in three to four semesters. Many of the courses are offered in the late afternoons and evenings to accommodate working students.
Accredidation: The Jennings A. Jones College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business-the premier accrediting agency for business schools.
ScholarshipPercentage: 100% of the in-state portion of tuition and fees

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting a satisfactory score on the TOEFL (79 iBT or 550 PBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE Academic (53), Duolingo (100), or by completing ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
In addition to the general requirements for admission to the College of Graduate Studies, applicants must have a bachelor's degree in geosciences or an equivalent degree that includes at least 30 semester hours in the geosciences (geology, geography, environmental science) or related sciences with at least a 2.75 GPA. Applicants with fewer than 30 semester hours of undergraduate coursework in geosciences may be required to complete additional undergraduate coursework, which will not count toward the M.S. degree.

Applicants must also submit to the Department of Geosciences

1. three letters of recommendation;
2. a statement of purpose (300-500 words) that describes their interests in the geosciences and their professional goals; and
3. a current resume.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Geosciences offers a curriculum designed to be relevant to today's employment trends and needs in the geosciences including environmental geoscience and geoarchaeology. The department is housed in the Davis Science Building, which includes facilities for remote sensing, GIS, geoarchaeology, paleontology, mineralogy, petrology, environmental chemistry, and hydrogeology. There are several active student organizations, including the student chapters of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists, the Association of Environmental & Engineering Geologists, and the National Speleological Society. The Department of Geosciences offers two options for the M.S. degree. A thesis option is available for students wishing to pursue research with a faculty member as part of the degree program. This is the more common degree option chosen by students who plan to enter a doctoral program or seek professional employment as a geologist. The non-thesis option provides a curriculum designed for students who are pursuing a career in geoscience education or for those students who are already established in their career and wish to further their education. Each student works closely with a graduate advisor who helps design an individualized curriculum based on the student's career objectives.
ScholarshipAmount: Minimum stipend of $10,000 for fall/spring plus a tuition waiver

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit evidence of English proficiency. Acceptable methods include: TOEFL (71 iBT or 525 PBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE Academic (54), Duolingo (100), or successful completion of the ELS Language Centers Level 112-Academic.
Requirements: To be considered for admission to the M.A. program, all applicants must submit the following materials: A completed online application form to the College of Graduate Studies; Official transcripts for all previous undergraduate and graduate work; Three letters of recommendation from former professors that speak to your academic potential; A statement of purpose (approximately 500 words) that discusses why you want to pursue a graduate degree in History, what you hope to do with that degree, and in what fields of history you are most interested; A sample of your academic writing (at least five pages), preferably a research paper based on primary sources that you have written for a history course; A resume or curriculum vitae; Official scores for the Graduate Record Exam (GRE), unless you have already earned a graduate degree from an accredited university or college.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Master of Arts in History at MTSU is a 30-hour program offering both thesis and non-thesis options. The program requires three core courses: HIST 6010 (Historiography), HIST 6020 (Historical Research and Writing), and one course in digital history. It then provides specialized training in either U.S. history or world history (including Europe). A concentration in Public History is also available. The program is designed to be completed in four full-time semesters. Students can complete the M.A. either on campus or through our fully online program. MTSU's M.A. in History is designed to meet the needs of a wide range of students, including those who plan to pursue a Ph.D. in history; those who plan to teach in community colleges, junior colleges, or secondary schools; those who are already teachers and want to improve their skills and earn a graduate degree; and those who want to enter the field of public history (archives, historic preservation, historical archaeology, and museums).

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English proficiency. Minimum scores are TOEFL 71 (Internet-based), IELTS 6.0, PTE Academic 48, or Duolingo English Test 100. Successful completion of ELS Language Centers level 112 also meets the requirement.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Arts in History program is competitive. Meeting minimum requirements for admission to the College of Graduate Studies does not guarantee admission into the M.A. in History program. Applicants seeking admission to the Master of Arts in History program must submit the following to the College of Graduate Studies: an application for admission; official transcripts of all previous college course work; three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to evaluate the applicant's potential for graduate work; a statement of purpose (approximately 500 words) indicating why the applicant wants to pursue graduate study in history at MTSU, his/her primary fields of interest, and his/her career goals; a writing sample (10-20 pages), preferably a research paper from an upper-division history course.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: MTSU's graduate programs in public history prepare students for careers in museums, historic preservation, archives and records management, oral history, cultural resource management, and other related fields. Our M.A. program in history with a concentration in public history is one of the oldest and largest in the country, and our Ph.D. in Public History is the only one of its kind in the world. As of Fall 2017, the M.A. concentration is available entirely via distance education. More than 450 of our alumni are working in public history fields around the world.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Professional Science
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-native English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency by one of the following: a minimum score of 71 on the Internet-based test (iBT) or 525 on the paper-based test (pbt); a minimum score of 6.0 on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS); a minimum score of 48 on the PTE Academic test; a minimum score of 95 on the Duolingo English test; or completion of level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: To be considered for admission to the Master of Science in Professional Science (MSPS) program, you must meet the admission requirements for the College of Graduate Studies and be accepted by the MSPS program. MSPS Program Admission Requirements include: An earned baccalaureate degree from an accredited university or college; Official transcripts of all previous college work; An acceptable grade point average (GPA) in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework (Unconditional admission requires a 3.0 GPA. Conditional admission requires a 2.75 GPA); Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose explaining your career goals and reasons for pursuing the MSPS degree; An up-to-date resume or curriculum vitae; Admission to the College of Graduate Studies; Acceptance by the MSPS Program. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is not required for MSPS applicants.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Concentration: ['Actuarial Sciences', 'Biostatistics', 'Biotechnology', 'Engineering Management', 'Geosciences', 'Health Care Informatics', 'Supply Chain Management']
Description: The Professional Science Master's (P.S.M.) is an innovative graduate degree designed to allow students to pursue advanced training in science or mathematics, while simultaneously developing workplace skills highly valued by employers. P.S.M. programs consist of two years of academic training in an emerging or interdisciplinary area, along with a professional component that may include internships and "cross-training" in workplace skills, such as business, communications, and regulatory affairs. All are designed in concert with employers and are designed to dovetail into present and future professional career opportunities.
Accredidation: Certified by the Commission on Affiliation of PSM programs.

ProgramName: Concentration in Professional Science - Actuarial Sciences
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate proficiency in the English language by submitting one of the following: TOEFL with a minimum score of 525 (paper-based) or 71 (Internet-based); IELTS with a minimum score of 6.0; PTE Academic with a minimum score of 54; Duolingo with a minimum score of 100; or documentation of completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Professional Science is an innovative graduate degree designed to allow students to pursue advanced training in a science or mathematics discipline while simultaneously developing highly valued business, communication, and regulatory skills. This interdisciplinary program prepares graduates for careers in business, industry, government, and the nonprofit sector where workforce needs are rapidly changing. Degree programs consist of a core of business and communication courses and a set of science or mathematics courses within a chosen concentration.

Requirements: Admission requirements for the Master of Science in Professional Science are the same as those for other master’s programs at MTSU. See Graduate Admissions. GRE scores are not required. Applicants must have an undergraduate major in a science, mathematics, or business field that is deemed appropriate by the M.S.P.S. Graduate Committee. Students with deficiencies may be required to take additional undergraduate coursework. Students select a concentration when they apply for admission. The program can be completed entirely online.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description:
The Master of Science in Professional Science is an innovative master’s degree program designed for students who wish to pursue advanced training in a science discipline and at the same time develop highly-valued business skills. The M.S.P.S. is a two-year program that combines a core curriculum of business and management courses with a student’s chosen science concentration. Graduates are prepared for careers in business, government, or non-profit sectors where scientific expertise and business fundamentals are needed.
Biotechnology is the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make useful products, or 'any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use' (UN Convention on Biological Diversity). Depending on the tools and applications, it often overlaps with the (related) fields of molecular biology, bio-engineering, biomedical engineering, biomanufacturing, molecular engineering, etc. For many centuries, humankind has used biotechnology in agriculture, food production, and medicine. The term is largely believed to have been coined in 1919 by Hungarian engineer Károly Ereky. In the late 20th and early 21st century, biotechnology has expanded to include new and diverse sciences such as genomics, recombinant gene techniques, applied immunology, and development of pharmaceutical therapies and diagnostic tests. A minor in Business is recommended for this concentration.
MinimumGreScore: 146 on the verbal portion and 144 on the quantitative portion

ProgramName: Concentration in Professional Science - Engineering Management
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores are: 71 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.0 on the IELTS, 95 on the Duolingo English Test, or 48 on the PTE Academic. Successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112 is also accepted.
Requirements: The College of Graduate Studies at MTSU requires that all students submit: An application and a non-refundable application fee. Official transcripts for all colleges and universities attended. The Master of Science in Professional Science also requires that students submit the following additional materials with their applications: Two letters of recommendation. A statement of purpose (approximately 300-500 words). A curriculum vitae (CV) or professional resume. Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. GRE General Test with a minimum Verbal score of 146 and a minimum Quantitative score of 144. In some cases, students may qualify for a GRE waiver.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Engineering Management concentration is one of six concentrations in the Master of Science in Professional Science (M.S.P.S.) degree program. This interdisciplinary program is designed for individuals with science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) backgrounds who wish to pursue management roles in their fields. The program combines advanced coursework from the College of Basic and Applied Sciences with graduate business and management coursework from the Jones College of Business. Students in the Engineering Management concentration complete a common core of business and management courses and a concentration core of engineering technology courses. The program is designed to provide graduates with the management skills needed to be effective leaders in technical organizations. This program is available both on-campus and fully online.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English proficiency. An official score report from one of the following is required: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English (PTE), Duolingo English Test, or ELS Language Centers.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Arts degree program in Psychology is granted by the Dean of the College of Graduate Studies upon the recommendation of the department's master's admissions committee. In addition to the university graduate admission requirements, the following departmental requirements must be met: a minimum GPA of 3.00 is generally required for admission to the M.A. programs, and applicants must have completed a minimum of 18 hours of undergraduate psychology coursework, including General Psychology, Statistics, and Research Methods. Applicants seeking admission to the Clinical, Experimental, or I/O Psychology M.A. program must submit the following directly to the Graduate School: Graduate application and application fee, Official transcripts, Three letters of recommendation, Statement of purpose (approximately 500 words), A résumé or curriculum vitae (CV). The GRE is not required for admission.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Master of Arts in Psychology program offers concentrations in Clinical, Experimental, Industrial-Organizational, Quantitative, and Pre-Specialist in School Psychology. The Clinical, Experimental, and I-O Psychology concentrations prepare students for doctoral study in these respective areas or for entry into master's-level careers. Students in the Quantitative Psychology concentration take a number of statistics and measurement courses to prepare for doctoral programs in quantitative psychology, educational measurement, and related fields or for careers in a variety of settings such as testing companies or research organizations. The School Psychology concentration prepares students for entry into the Specialist in Education (Ed.S.) program in School Psychology at MTSU, as completion of the Ed.S. is required for licensure as a school psychologist. All concentrations require a common core of courses as well as courses in the student's area of interest.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English are required to provide TOEFL or IELTS scores.
Requirements: The Quantitative Psychology concentration will admit students for Fall only. Deadline for applications is January 15. In addition to the admission requirements for the College of Graduate Studies, the M.A. program in Psychology requires an official transcript showing a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university with a major in psychology or a minimum of 18 semester hours of psychology course work; an undergraduate GPA of 3.00; Graduate Record Exam (GRE) scores; three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to make a sound judgment of the applicant’s academic potential; and a one- to two-page statement of purpose.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Master of Arts in Psychology is a versatile degree. The Quantitative Psychology concentration prepares students for doctoral programs in psychology or for careers in which research and data analytic skills are central. The program provides strong training in research methodology, statistics, and measurement, with a variety of basic and applied psychology courses.

Requirements:
Applicants for the M.A. in Psychology with a concentration in Industrial/Organizational Psychology should submit the following to the College of Graduate Studies:

An application for admission.
Official transcripts of all previous college work.
Official scores on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE). A waiver of the GRE requirement is available for select applicants. For more information, please visit the Psychology department’s admissions page.
Three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to make an academic appraisal.
A current resume or vitae.
A statement of purpose of approximately 500 words describing the applicant’s interest in I/O psychology and career aspirations.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Industrial/Organizational (I/O) Psychology master's program at MTSU is dedicated to the scientific study of human behavior in work settings. The program follows a scientist-practitioner model, which emphasizes the connection of science and practice. Students in the program can expect to learn about the major areas of I/O psychology: personnel psychology (e.g., selection, performance appraisal, and training), organizational psychology (e.g., motivation, leadership, and work attitudes), and health and safety in the workplace. Students learn through a combination of coursework and hands-on experience by completing an internship and a thesis. Upon completing the program, students can pursue positions in a variety of industries (e.g., consulting, manufacturing, healthcare, and government), as well as continue their education in doctoral programs. For students interested in a doctoral degree, our program has an excellent placement rate in I/O psychology doctoral programs. The Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology (SIOP) publishes guidelines for master's-level training in I/O psychology. The M.A. in I/O Psychology program at MTSU follows the SIOP guidelines. The I/O psychology M.A. program is a member of the Council for Applied Master's Programs in Psychology (CAMPP).
Accredidation: The M.A. in I/O Psychology program at MTSU follows the SIOP guidelines. The I/O psychology M.A. program is a member of the Council for Applied Master's Programs in Psychology (CAMPP).
MinimumGreScore: target minimum scores of 147 verbal, 147 quantitative, and 4.0 analytic writing
ScholarshipAmount: The minimum stipend for a full-time (20 hours/week) master's graduate assistant is $8,000 for the academic year.

ProgramName: Doctor of Philosophy in Public History
EnglishScore: International applicants must have a minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based) or 79-80 (iBT) or IELTS score of 6.0 or PTE score of 53 or Duolingo score of 100.
Requirements: Admission to the Ph.D. in Public History is competitive. Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission. Applicants must meet the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies. In addition, applicants must hold a Master of Arts degree in history, public history, historic preservation, museum studies, or a closely related discipline from an accredited institution. Applicants must submit official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Applicants must have a minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.5 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate coursework attempted. In addition to the documents required by the College of Graduate Studies, applicants must submit the following directly to the History Department: three letters of recommendation from individuals able to assess the applicant's academic abilities and potential for success in a doctoral program; a curriculum vitae (CV); a statement of purpose that describes why the applicant is interested in MTSU's doctoral program, future career goals, and the public history fields in which he or she is interested; a writing sample that demonstrates the ability to conduct historical research and analysis.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Concentration: Historic Preservation/Cultural Resource Management, Museum Management
Description: The Public History Ph.D. program at MTSU offers students the opportunity to earn a doctoral degree in a field that has seen tremendous growth in recent decades. The program offers a broad exposure to the historical sub-disciplines necessary to be a successful public historian in the 21st century. It is the first doctoral program in the field in Tennessee and is unique in its breadth and focus. The program also draws on the Center for Historic Preservation, the Albert Gore Research Center, and the work of our nationally recognized faculty in public history, historic preservation, and American history. MTSU has one of the largest public history and historic preservation faculties in the nation. Students can choose to study in historic preservation/cultural resource management or museum management. Courses in digital history, documentary filmmaking, and oral history allow all students to broaden their experiences. Students from all over the country and all over the world come to MTSU to receive hands-on training from our faculty. Graduate assistantships at the Center for Historic Preservation, the Gore Center, and with Public History faculty provide financial assistance and allow students to work with a range of community partners and clients. These experiences, plus a required internship, prepare students to become public history professionals or to take positions in academia. Our graduates work in a variety of public history jobs in Tennessee and across the country.
MinimumGreScore: combined verbal and quantitative score of 300 and an analytical writing score of 4.0

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Recording Arts and Technologies
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate proficiency in the English language by submitting one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) with a minimum score of 71 (iBT) or 525 (PBT); International English Language Testing System (IELTS) with a minimum score of 6.0; Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic with a minimum score of 52; Duolingo English Test with a minimum score of 100; or a Certificate of completion of Level 112 from an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: Applicants must have a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must have an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. Applicants must submit three letters of recommendation. Applicants must submit a statement of purpose detailing their career goals and reasons for pursuing the M.F.A. degree. Applicants must submit a portfolio demonstrating significant creative work. Applicants must submit a résumé detailing their professional and educational experience. Applicants must participate in an interview with the M.F.A. faculty.
Department: College of Media and Entertainment
Description: The Master of Fine Arts in Recording Arts and Technologies is a terminal degree program designed to prepare students for careers in audio production, research, and post-secondary education. The M.F.A. requires the satisfactory completion of 60 semester hours of graduate credit and is structured to be completed in two calendar years. The first year is focused on advanced recording and mixing techniques in both surround sound and stereo, as well as an introduction to audio research. Students will have significant lab time in MTSU’s world-class recording studios. The second year focuses on one of two concentrations: audio production or audio resources.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Aeronautical Science
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. An official score report from an approved English proficiency exam must be sent directly from the testing agency to the College of Graduate Studies. Applicants who have earned a bachelor’s degree or higher from a U.S. institution are exempt from this requirement.
Requirements:
Applicants must meet the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies. Applicants must also have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. In addition, admission will be granted based on one of the following two options:

Option 1: An undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or higher

Option 2: An undergraduate GPA of 2.75 to 2.99 and a satisfactory score on the Miller Analogies Test (MAT) or the Graduate Record Examination (GRE).
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Concentration: ['Aviation Education', 'Aviation Management', 'Aviation Safety and Security Management', 'Unmanned Aircraft Systems Operations']
Description: The Master of Science in Aeronautical Science (M.S.A.S.) is designed to provide students with a technically oriented and specialized professional master's degree in aviation. The program is specifically for those who wish to work in the many technically advanced and specialized segments of the aviation and aerospace industry. The M.S.A.S. program continues the MTSU Aerospace Department's tradition of bringing together a nationally recognized faculty of experts with an exceptional student body to provide a graduate program of the highest quality. Students can pursue the degree with a thesis option or with a non-thesis option. The thesis option involves the completion of 30 semester hours of coursework. The non-thesis option is comprised of 33 semester hours of coursework.
Accredidation: The Master of Science in Aeronautical Science is accredited by the Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI).
MinimumGreScore: 294 (new test) or 950 (old test) with 2.7 GPA; 297 (new test) or 1000 (old test) with GPA below 2.7

EnglishScore: Provide proof of English proficiency by meeting one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) score of 525 (paper-based), 195 (computer-based), or 71 (Internet-based) or higher; International English Language Testing System (IELTS) academic score of 6.0 or higher; Pearson Test of English (PTE) academic score of 52 or higher; Duolingo English Test score of 95 or higher; Successful completion of the ELS Language Centers level 112; Proof of degree from a country where English is the official language; Successful completion of MTSU's Intensive English Program.
Requirements:
Admission to the Master of Science in Aviation requires:
1. An undergraduate degree from an accredited institution.
2. A minimum GPA of 2.75 in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework.
3. A score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test of at least 143 Verbal, 144 Quantitative, and 3.5 Analytical. NOTE: the GRE requirement is currently waived through Fall 2026.
4. Two letters of recommendation.
5. Statement of Purpose outlining the applicant's background and goals for the program.
6. Curriculum vitae (CV) or resume.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science degree with a concentration in Aviation Education is designed to provide students with a relevant and focused study of aviation education, training, and research. This concentration is designed for individuals who aspire to enter or advance in an aviation career with a focus on education or training. The concentration appeals to a wide variety of students including K-12 educators, postsecondary aviation faculty, flight instructors, aviation training center instructors, curriculum designers, and many other aviation-related education/training careers. The curriculum provides an in-depth exploration of learning theories, instructional design and delivery, curriculum development, educational assessment, educational research, and educational technology as they relate to the aviation industry.
Accredidation: The M.S. in Aerospace is accredited by the Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI).
MinimumGreScore: Formula: (200 x GPA + GRE V&Q score) >= 1000
MinimumMATScore: Formula: (15 x GPA + MAT score) >= 1000 (only applicable to applicants with at least three years of professional aviation experience)

EnglishScore: Applicants from non-native English speaking countries must demonstrate English proficiency. Applicants who cannot provide proof of English proficiency may be considered for Conditional Admission.
Requirements:
Applicants to the Master of Science in Aviation program must satisfy the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies as well as the specific program requirements.

Admission Requirements

Applicants must have a minimum cumulative undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale to be unconditionally admitted. In addition, an applicant must satisfy at least one of the following criteria to be unconditionally admitted:

1. A GRE score of at least 146 on the verbal portion, 144 on the quantitative portion, and a 3.5 on the analytical writing portion of the test, OR
2. A GMAT total score of at least 450, OR
3. Possess an undergraduate degree from MTSU's Department of Aerospace, OR
4. Possess a commercial pilot certificate with an instrument rating or an FAA aircraft dispatcher certificate, OR
5. Have a total of at least three years of professional aviation industry experience.

Applicants not meeting the GPA and the additional requirements for unconditional admission may be conditionally admitted. The conditional student must earn a B (3.0) or better in the first nine (9) semester hours to become a degree-seeking student. In addition, an applicant must satisfy at least one of the following criteria to be conditionally admitted:

1. A GRE score of at least 143 on the verbal portion, 140 on the quantitative portion, and a 3.0 on the analytical writing portion of the test, OR
2. A GMAT total score of at least 400.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Aviation Management concentration is a business-oriented, non-flying degree program designed for students seeking to enter the management side of aviation. The curriculum offers a unique blend of business and aviation courses taught by experienced industry professionals. Graduates go on to leadership positions with airlines, airports, aircraft manufacturers, government organizations (FAA and NASA), consulting firms, and corporate flight departments. Students gain a working knowledge of airline and airport management, aviation law and regulations, aviation safety, and business principles. The curriculum also includes instruction on air traffic control and unmanned aircraft systems (drones).
Accredidation: MTSU’s Aerospace Department is a signature department of the University and has earned a national and international reputation for excellence. We are accredited by the Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI), which is the highest standard of achievement for aviation programs. In fact, MTSU is one of only seven universities in the country to have AABI accreditation in five or more concentrations.

ProgramName: Concentration in Aviation Safety and Security Management
EnglishScore: For applicants whose native language is not English, proof of English proficiency is required. This can be demonstrated with a minimum score of 525 on the TOEFL PBT, 71 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.0 on the IELTS, 51 on the PTE, or 100 on the Duolingo test. Completion of ELS Language Centers level 112 or a bachelor's or master's degree from an accredited U.S. institution also satisfies this requirement.
Requirements: Applicants must meet the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies. Applicants must have an undergraduate degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must have a minimum cumulative undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale. Applicants must submit an official score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test (or an acceptable substitute like the Miller Analogies Test (MAT) or the Graduate Management Admissions Test (GMAT). GRE: 291 (verbal + quantitative); new test format effective August 2011; GRE: verbal, 143; quantitative, 141; MAT: 380; GMAT: 450; The GRE requirement will be waived for applicants with five or more years of relevant, professional aviation experience. The GRE analytical writing is not considered for admission purposes. Applicants must submit official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. International applicants must demonstrate English proficiency.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Aviation Safety and Security Management concentration is one of three concentrations offered as part of the Master of Science in Aviation degree. MTSU’s M.S. in Aviation with a concentration in Aviation Safety and Security Management is one of only a few such programs in the nation. It provides students with comprehensive aviation safety and security coursework designed for professional advancement. The concentration includes unique courses such as Aviation Security, Advanced Aviation Safety, Aviation Accident Investigation, Crew Resource Management, and a graduate capstone project. This program will also allow graduates to earn a graduate certificate in Aviation Safety and Security along with the Master’s degree. Students are encouraged to pursue an industry internship. In addition, students complete an appropriate 3-credit capstone experience.
Accredidation: The M.S. in Aviation program is accredited by the Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI).
MinimumGreScore: 291 (verbal + quantitative) and 3.0 on the analytical writing

ProgramName: Master of Science in Horse Science
EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: a minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 79 (Internet-based); a minimum IELTS score of 6.0; a minimum PTE score of 53; a minimum Duolingo score of 110; or a minimum ELS score of 112.
Requirements: Admission to the M.S. in Horse Science requires a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must meet the admission standards of the College of Graduate Studies. Applicants who do not hold a bachelor’s degree in an animal or horse science discipline must have completed a minimum of 18 undergraduate hours of coursework in this area. Prerequisite coursework must include introductory animal/horse science, anatomy and physiology, nutrition, and reproduction. Other courses may be required at the discretion of the program graduate coordinator. Applicants who do not meet this standard may be admitted conditionally and will be required to complete these courses prior to full admission.
Department: School of Agriculture
Concentration: Equine Education, Equine Physiology, and Industry Management
Description: The Master of Science in Horse Science is a 33-hour degree program with three concentration options: Equine Education, Equine Physiology, and Industry Management. All concentrations require a common core of graduate-level courses that may be applied to any of the concentrations. The required core classes are designed to provide students with a deeper understanding of equine science topics while enhancing their critical-thinking and problem-solving skills. The Master of Science (M.S.) degree in Horse Science offers advanced study in equine science and related subjects. Students will develop skills in research, teaching, and extension methods while increasing their knowledge in specialized areas.

ProgramName: Concentration in Horse Science - Industry Management
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting official scores, less than two years old, from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Duolingo English Test, or Pearson Test of English Academic (PTE Academic). Completion of the ELS Language Centers Level 112 is also acceptable.
Requirements:
Applicants for the M.S. in Horse Science must submit an application and supporting documents to the College of Graduate Studies. Admission to the M.S. in Horse Science is competitive. Applicants will be judged on the following criteria:

Undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher
Graduate Record Exam (GRE) scores (The GRE is waived for applicants with a 3.25 undergraduate GPA or higher.)
A 500-word statement of purpose outlining career goals
Three letters of recommendation
A résumé
Department: School of Agriculture
Description: The Master of Science in Horse Science offers a concentration in Industry Management. This program is a 33-hour, non-thesis degree plan. Core courses are online while concentration courses are offered on campus. This degree offers a comprehensive and in-depth study of the equine sciences and related industry practices and is designed for individuals who desire an advanced degree in the equine field. Faculty are well-respected, nationally-known equine experts, and MTSU is well recognized in the horse industry as an institution that produces well-qualified graduates.

ProgramName: Master of Education in Professional Counseling
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT score of 71 (no subscore below 16 in any section); International English Language Testing System (IELTS) score of 6.0; Pearson Test of English (PTE) academic score of 54; Duolingo English Test score of 100; ELS Language Centers level 112 with a 2.5 GPA or higher.
Requirements:
Applicants seeking admission to the Professional Counseling Program should follow the admission procedures outlined in the Graduate Catalog. In addition, applicants must:

- submit an online application for admission to the College of Graduate Studies.
- have an undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
- have completed the following prerequisite undergraduate courses: Abnormal Psychology, Theories of Personality, and Developmental Psychology (lifespan).
- submit a resume.
- submit a two- to three-page, double-spaced personal statement addressing: (a) reasons for choosing the counseling profession; (b) personal strengths and weaknesses; (c) characteristics that will contribute to being an effective counselor; (d) experiences that have directed them to the counseling profession; and (e) other information the applicant deems relevant to the admission decision.
- submit a writing sample from one of the prerequisite courses, preferably from Abnormal Psychology or Theories of Personality.
- submit three letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to the applicant's academic and professional potential (e.g., professor, work supervisor). At least one letter should be from a professor.
- participate in a personal interview with the Professional Counseling Program Admissions Committee.
Department: College of Education
Concentration: Clinical Mental Health Counseling, School Counseling
Description: The Professional Counseling Program at Middle Tennessee State University provides graduate-level training for individuals who wish to become professional counselors. The program has a practitioner-based focus emphasizing the development of knowledge and skills necessary for the practice of professional counseling. The Professional Counseling Program offers two concentrations: Clinical Mental Health Counseling and School Counseling. The M.Ed. in Professional Counseling is a 60-credit-hour program that meets the educational requirements for licensure in Tennessee as a Licensed Professional Counselor (LPC) or as a Licensed School Counselor. Graduates of both program concentrations have a 100% pass rate on their respective licensure exams for the past several years.
Accredidation: The Clinical Mental Health Counseling and School Counseling programs at Middle Tennessee State University are accredited by the Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP).

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Psychology (Clinical Psychology)
EnglishScore: All applicants who are not native speakers of English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting a score from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or the International English Language Testing System (IELTS). A minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based) or 79-80 (Internet-based) or a minimum IELTS score of 6.5 is required.
Requirements:
Admission to the M.A. program in Clinical Psychology is a two-step process. In order to be considered for regular admission to the M.A. in Clinical Psychology, applicants must first be granted admission to the College of Graduate Studies. Admission to the College of Graduate Studies requires:
1. An official transcript for the bachelor's degree from an accredited institution.
2. An undergraduate GPA of at least 2.75 on a 4.0 scale for regular admission and 2.5 for conditional admission.

Program Specific Admission Requirements
1. An undergraduate major in psychology OR a minimum of 18 semester hours in psychology, including the following five courses: General Psychology, Statistics, Research Methods, Abnormal Psychology, and Personality Psychology.
2. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
3. Three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to judge the applicant's academic potential. At least two of the three letters must be from faculty members.
4. A statement of purpose of about 500 words describing the applicant's research interests, career goals, and the reasons for wishing to enter the Clinical Psychology M.A. program at MTSU.
5. A resume or curriculum vitae.

The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is NOT required for admission.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The M.A. in Clinical Psychology program prepares students for Ph.D. programs in clinical or counseling psychology and/or for employment as psychological associates in clinical settings. The curriculum is designed to provide students with a firm foundation in psychology. All students are required to complete courses in the major areas of psychology, in psychological assessment, and in the theory and practice of psychotherapy. Additionally, all students complete a 500-hour practicum at a community agency and a thesis.
Accredidation: The Master of Arts in Clinical Psychology is accredited by the Masters in Psychology and Counseling Accreditation Council (MPCAC) for the period of August 2014 through August 2024.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. This may be done by submitting a TOEFL score of 71 (iBT), an IELTS score of 6.0, a PTE Academic score of 53, a Duolingo score of 100, or by completing ELS Language Center's Level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the M.A. program in Experimental Psychology is competitive. Applicants are selected on the basis of several factors, including letters of recommendation, statement of purpose, academic background and performance, research experience, and GRE scores. To be considered for admission, applicants must have: an undergraduate degree from an accredited university or college; an undergraduate background which includes at least 15 semester hours in psychology including a course in statistics and a course in research methods/experimental psychology; a minimum overall undergraduate GPA of 3.00. a curriculum vitae or resume; three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with applicant's academic and/or research potential. Letters should be sent directly by the recommenders. Instructions are provided with the online application. a statement of purpose indicating the applicant's research interests, career goals, and the faculty with whom the student is interested in working. The statement of purpose should not exceed two double-spaced pages. Note: Due to challenges associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, the GRE will not be required for Fall 2024 admissions.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Experimental Psychology M.A. Program at Middle Tennessee State University is designed to prepare students for doctoral-level study in all areas of experimental psychology or for master’s-level careers in applied research. Experimental psychology broadly refers to the scientific study of psychological processes in human and non-human animals. At MTSU, students can focus on a wide variety of research areas within this discipline, such as cognitive, developmental, industrial/organizational, learning, physiological, or social psychology. The program is specifically tailored for each student, with a focus on psychological research. All students are required to become actively involved in research during their first semester of study, with the goal of producing a high-quality master’s thesis by the end of their second year. The program requires 36 hours of graduate coursework, including nine hours of statistics and research design courses and six hours of thesis research.
ScholarshipAmount: Approximately $7,000 for the nine-month academic year

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Psychology (Pre-Specialist in Education - School Psychology Concentration)
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit proof of English proficiency by providing an official score report of one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English Academic (PTE Academic), Duolingo, or ELS.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Concentration: Pre-Specialist in Education - School Psychology Concentration
Description: This program prepares students for entrance into the Specialist in Education (Ed.S.) degree program in School Psychology at MTSU. The M.A. is not a terminal degree and does not lead to licensure. Students must complete the Ed.S. degree to be eligible for licensure as a school psychologist. However, this M.A. program provides students with experiences and skills needed for success in the Ed.S. program and is a prerequisite for entry into the Ed.S. program for those who do not already have a master’s degree in a related field. Students are required to complete a 150-hour practicum that serves as an introduction to school psychological services in the school setting. Students have the opportunity to work in a variety of research labs on topics including autism spectrum disorders, bullying, reading interventions, and academic assessment. NOTE: Admission to this program is for fall only.
MinimumGreScore: preferred combined GRE Verbal and Quantitative score of 297 (1000 on the old GRE) and a preferred score on the GRE Writing Assessment of 4.0

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Psychology (Quantitative Psychology)
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must submit one of the following as proof of English proficiency: a minimum score of 525 on the paper-based (PBT) or 71 on the internet-based (iBT) is required on the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL); a minimum score of 6.0 is required on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS); a minimum score of 54 is required on the Pearson Test of English (PTE); a minimum score of 95 is required on the Duolingo English Test; or successful completion of ELS (English Language Services) level 112 is required.
Requirements:
Admission to the M.A. in Psychology is competitive and based on a combination of factors, including GPA (overall and in psychology), GRE scores, letters of recommendation, and a personal statement.

Admission requirements for the College of Graduate Studies are met in addition to the following:

1. An official transcript showing a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university. Preference is given to applicants with a minimum GPA of 3.00.
2. Official Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores. GRE is currently being waived for applicants. Please check back regularly for updates. If an applicant has taken the GRE and would like for their scores to be considered as part of their application, please contact the program coordinator. Preference is given to students with scores above the 50th percentile on the verbal and quantitative sections.
3. Three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to evaluate the applicant's potential for success in a graduate program.
4. A one- to two-page statement of purpose that describes academic and professional goals and how they can be met through our program. For the quantitative psychology concentration, please describe your statistical and programming experience and background in the personal statement.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Quantitative Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students for doctoral-level study in quantitative psychology or for master's-level careers in research and data analysis in education, government, and the private sector. The curriculum includes two semesters of statistics (ANOVA and regression), as well as courses in measurement, multivariate statistics, and a variety of elective courses in psychology and research methods. Student research is a primary component of the quantitative program, and students have opportunities to collaborate on research projects with a number of faculty in the department. Quantitative students will complete and defend a master’s thesis.

EnglishScore: MTSU requires a minimum TOEFL score of 525 (paper-based), 195 (computer-based), or 71 (Internet-based); a minimum IELTS score of 6.0; a minimum PTE score of 48; a minimum Duolingo score of 95; or successful completion of the ELS Language Center's Level 112 to be considered for admission.
Requirements:
In addition to the university’s minimum requirements, applicants for admission to the Master of Accountancy program must meet one of the following criteria:

- An undergraduate degree in accounting from an AACSB-accredited institution with a GPA of 3.000 or greater.
- An undergraduate degree from an AACSB-accredited business school with a GPA of 3.250 or greater and completion of the six accounting courses from an AACSB school that are prerequisite to the graduate accounting courses at MTSU (see below).
- An undergraduate degree from a regionally accredited university with a GPA of 3.250 or greater, a GMAT score of 500 or greater, and completion of the six accounting courses from an AACSB school that are prerequisite to the graduate accounting courses at MTSU (see below).
- Completion of 18 hours of graduate coursework at a regionally accredited university with a GPA of 3.500 or greater and completion of the six accounting courses from an AACSB school that are prerequisite to the graduate accounting courses at MTSU (see below).

The six prerequisite courses are Intermediate I, Intermediate II, Cost, Tax, Auditing, and Accounting Information Systems. Applicants who do not meet one of the above may be admitted on the basis of a combination of GPA and GMAT score using the formula: (GPA x 200) + GMAT > 1050.

In order to apply, please submit the following:

- an application with the application fee
- official transcripts of all previous college work
- official GMAT scores (if required)
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Master of Accountancy (M.Acc.) is a professional graduate program designed to prepare students for careers in public, private, and governmental accounting. The M.Acc. meets the educational requirements for students to sit for the CPA exam in Tennessee and most other states. The curriculum is designed to enhance the professional competencies of students with an undergraduate degree in accounting.
Accredidation: MTSU's Accounting program, housed in the Jennings A. Jones College of Business, is accredited by AACSB International—The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

EnglishScore: All international students are required to demonstrate English language proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include: TOEFL iBT 71, TOEFL PBT 525, IELTS 6.0, PTE 48, Duolingo 100, or completion of ELS level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Criminal Justice program is based on a holistic review of each applicant’s file. Admission requires the following: Admission to the College of Graduate Studies; Baccalaureate degree from an accredited university or college with a cumulative minimum GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale; Scores on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) or the Miller Analogies Test (MAT); Three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with the applicant’s academic and/or professional capabilities; A letter of intent/purpose that outlines the reasons for applying to the M.C.J. program and how the degree will help achieve the applicant’s personal and professional goals; A current resume.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Master of Criminal Justice (M.C.J.) degree is for those who want to advance in the criminal justice field, teach at the community college level, or prepare for doctoral-level studies. Offered entirely online, this 36-hour program consists of a 15-hour core, 15 hours of electives, and a 6-hour capstone experience (thesis or professional project).

ProgramName: Master of Science in Engineering Management
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-English speaking countries must submit one of the following to demonstrate English proficiency: TOEFL - 71 iBT (Internet-based) or 525 PBT (paper-based); IELTS - 6.0; PTE academic - 54; Duolingo - 100; ELS - 112.
Requirements:
Admission to the Master of Science program in Engineering Management requires:

An undergraduate degree in engineering, technology, mathematics, physics, or a closely related field from an accredited university or college;
An undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or better on a 4.0 scale for unconditional admission. Conditional admission may be considered for applicants with GPAs between 2.75 and 3.0.
GRE is no longer required for admission.
For international applicants who native language is not English, a minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper based) or 213 (computer based) or 79-80 (Internet based) or a minimum IELTS score of 6.5 or a minimum Duolingo English Test of 110 is required.
All students must be admitted to the College of Graduate Studies. International applicants must also be admitted through the Office of International Affairs.

Application materials should be submitted to the College of Graduate Studies and include: an application form; official transcripts of all college work; and three letters of recommendation.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
