ScholarshipAmount: Up to $5,000/year for guaranteed freshman scholarships

Requirements:
To be eligible for admission to MTSU, you must meet the following academic requirements. You must meet the same high school unit requirements as a first-time freshman and have a 2.0 GPA on all prior college coursework.

Guaranteed Admission Requirements (must meet one):
- 3.0 GPA or higher
- 2.5 GPA or higher AND 22 ACT (1100 SAT)
- 2.7 GPA or higher AND 20 ACT (1020 SAT)

Test Optional Admission: Students who do not wish to provide an ACT or SAT score and have a 3.0 or higher cumulative high school GPA will be offered admission to MTSU.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: Sociology is the scientific study of human society, social behavior, and social structure. Sociologists examine how social forces influence individual behavior, group dynamics, and societal institutions. Students in the Sociology program develop a strong foundation in sociological theory, research methods, and data analysis. They gain critical thinking skills, cultural awareness, and a global perspective applicable to diverse career paths. The B.A. degree emphasizes a broad liberal arts education, while the B.S. degree focuses on quantitative skills and research applications. Our program prepares students for various professions in fields such as social work, counseling, public administration, law, education, journalism, urban planning, human resources, market research, and non-profit management. It also provides an excellent foundation for graduate studies in sociology or related disciplines.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $545.00/credit hour; Out-of-State: $1,159.00/credit hour (for Fall 2024 - Spring 2025)
ScholarshipAmount: Guaranteed scholarships range from $3,500 to $8,000 per year

EnglishScore: All applicants from countries where English is not the native language must submit evidence of English proficiency. Minimum Score Requirements for Unconditional Admission: TOEFL (iBT) - 61, IELTS - 5.5, PTE Academic - 48, Duolingo - 95, ELS Language Center - Level 109.
Requirements: To be considered for guaranteed admission, you need to meet one of the following academic criteria: 3.0 GPA or higher OR ACT composite score of 22 or higher OR SAT composite of 1100 or higher (combined Evidence-Based Reading and Writing + Math). In addition, you must complete the required 14 high school units.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Sociology, Criminology Concentration, is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in the study of crime and the criminal justice system. The curriculum includes courses on theoretical explanations of crime, research methods in criminology, social control, and various aspects of the justice system such as policing, courts, and corrections. Students will develop critical thinking skills, analytical abilities, and an understanding of social justice issues related to crime and punishment. Students in the Criminology Concentration will gain a comprehensive understanding of the causes and consequences of crime, as well as the societal responses to it. The program emphasizes critical thinking and analytical skills, preparing students for a variety of careers in criminal justice, social work, law, and public service. Graduates are well-prepared for roles in law enforcement, probation and parole, victim advocacy, and correctional facilities, or for further graduate studies. Our faculty are experts in various subfields of criminology, providing students with up-to-date knowledge and diverse perspectives. The program also offers opportunities for internships, giving students practical experience in real-world settings.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts range from $2,000 to $3,500 per year; some scholarships cover full tuition.

EnglishScore: Proof of English proficiency is required for international applicants. Accepted tests include TOEFL (71 iBT / 525 PBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE (53), or Duolingo (100). Completion of ELS Level 112 is also accepted, among other exemptions.
Requirements: MTSU will use a holistic review process that combines a student's GPA and test scores (if provided) to determine admission. Students with a 3.0 GPA or higher who choose not to submit a test score will be admitted. Students with a GPA between 2.7-2.99 who choose not to submit a test score will be reviewed through our holistic review process and could be asked to submit additional information, including an essay, to be considered for admission. Students with test scores (21 ACT/1060 SAT or higher) and a 2.7 GPA or higher will be admitted. Students with test scores (17-20 ACT/920-1050 SAT) and a 3.0 GPA or higher will be admitted.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Sociology with a concentration in Social Justice provides students with a strong theoretical and methodological foundation in the study of society, with a particular emphasis on understanding and addressing social inequality, human rights, and advocacy. This concentration prepares students for careers in social justice organizations, community activism, public policy, and further graduate study in sociology, law, social work, and related fields. Students will develop critical thinking, research, and communication skills essential for analyzing complex social problems and advocating for positive social change.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum score requirements for undergraduate admission include TOEFL iBT 61 (or PBT 500), IELTS 5.5, PTE Academic 48, or Duolingo 95. Successful completion of ELS Level 112 also meets the requirement.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
CostPerCredit: In-state: ~$416/hour; Out-of-state: ~$1,259/hour (based on 2023-24 rates including fees)

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English are required to submit proof of English proficiency. Accepted tests include TOEFL with a minimum score of 71 iBT (or 525 PBT), IELTS with a minimum score of 6.0, PTE Academic with a minimum score of 48, Duolingo English Test with a minimum score of 100, or completion of ELS Language Center Level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology major is based upon meeting the regular requirements for admission to MTSU. Please check the Undergraduate Admissions website for specific details.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology is an academic discipline focused on the study of normal and disordered human communication. This includes articulation, voice, fluency, language, swallowing, and hearing. Speech-language pathologists and audiologists provide services for the prevention, identification, evaluation, and treatment of speech, language, swallowing, and hearing disorders. Both professions require a master's or doctoral degree after the bachelor's degree to practice professionally. A bachelor’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology is an excellent preparatory degree for graduate study in speech-language pathology and audiology, as well as related fields. The curriculum for the B.S. degree provides the foundational knowledge necessary for graduate work in these professions. Graduates with a bachelor’s degree are also prepared to work as paraprofessionals in a variety of settings (e.g., speech-language pathology assistants, audiology assistants, teachers of the deaf or hard of hearing).

EnglishScore: International applicants must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be met by providing a minimum score on one of the following tests: TOEFL iBT 71, TOEFL PBT 525, IELTS 6.0, PTE Academic 48, or Duolingo English Test 95. Successful completion of ELS Level 112 is also accepted. Other exemptions may apply.
Requirements: First-time freshmen are assured admission if they have a 3.0 GPA. For applicants with a GPA between 2.7 and 2.99, a 19 ACT or 990 SAT is required. Students not meeting either of these requirements will be reviewed for admission through a holistic review.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Concentration: Acting, Design, Directing, Theatre Education, Stage Management
Description: The Theatre Program at MTSU emphasizes the liberal arts and trains students for a variety of futures in professional theatre, educational theatre, and graduate school. The program provides students with broad-based theatre education with opportunities for specialization within the curriculum. Students gain practical experience through active participation in productions and work with faculty who are active professionals, artists, and scholars. Our commitment to high quality, diverse programming, and experiential learning ensures that our students are well prepared for the future.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be done by submitting one of the following: TOEFL (500 PBT / 61 iBT), IELTS (5.5), PTE Academic (45), Duolingo (95), or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: In addition to university admission, this program requires an audition for acceptance.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Theatre-Teacher Licensure Concentration (B.S.) provides students with a broad and in-depth preparation for a teaching career in theatre arts at the secondary school level. It also prepares students for further graduate study in theatre education. Graduates of the program are prepared to teach all areas of theatre arts in middle and high school as well as serve as directors of school theatre productions. The curriculum combines courses in acting, directing, design, theatre history, dramatic literature, and playwriting with courses in education, teaching methods, and student teaching.

ProgramName: Aerospace B.S. (Aerospace Technology, Flight Dispatch and Maintenance Management only)
EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate proficiency by providing a minimum score from one of the following: TOEFL (500 PBT / 61 iBT), IELTS (5.5), PTE Academic (46), Duolingo (95), or by successfully completing Level 112 of the ELS Language Center program.
Requirements: To be admitted to MTSU, you must meet one of the following: Complete the pre-college curriculum with a minimum 3.0 GPA, OR; Obtain a minimum 2.7 GPA and a minimum 22 ACT (1100 SAT), OR; Have a minimum 22 ACT (1100 SAT)
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Concentration: Aerospace Technology, Flight Dispatch, Maintenance Management
Description: The MTSU Aerospace professional pilot degree program has received national and international acclaim as one of the best programs in the country. Our graduates fly for major and regional airlines, cargo companies, military operations, and corporate flight departments. Other graduates find employment in airport management, aerospace technology, aviation management, flight dispatch, maintenance management, and air traffic control. Whether you choose to fly or work on the ground, MTSU Aerospace will prepare you for an exciting and rewarding career in the aerospace industry.
Accredidation: The Maintenance Management concentration is accredited by the Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI).

Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The goal of this project is to provide undergraduate students with an experiential learning opportunity that will equip them with the analytical and data science skills necessary to make data-driven decisions in the agricultural sector. The project targets students in underrepresented groups and those who are first-generation college students, rural residents, and military veterans and dependents. Students participating in the program will be known as Agri-Analytics Fellows. Fellows will receive training in analytical tools, decision-making, and communication and professional skills through a short-course series and an internship with an agricultural business or government agency. Faculty from the Department of Agribusiness and Agriscience and the Data Science Institute at Middle Tennessee State University will deliver the short-courses, and faculty from partner institutions will provide additional training. Through this project, fellows will not only expand career pathways but also meet the demand for a highly skilled workforce that is prepared to tackle the challenges of 21st century agriculture.

EnglishScore: International applicants must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores include TOEFL iBT 61, IELTS 5.5, PTE Academic 53, or Duolingo 95. Completion of ELS level 112 also meets the requirement.
Requirements: Assured admission is granted to applicants with a high school GPA of 3.0 or higher OR applicants with a high school GPA of 2.7 or higher AND an ACT composite of 22 or higher (or SAT equivalent of 1100 or higher).
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Biochemistry at Middle Tennessee State University is designed to give students a comprehensive background in modern biochemistry. This includes a strong foundation in the fundamentals of chemistry and biology, as well as specialized coursework in areas such as enzymology, metabolism, molecular biology, and proteomics. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for careers in biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, research, and healthcare, or for further graduate studies in biochemistry, molecular biology, medicine, or related fields. The program emphasizes hands-on laboratory experience and provides opportunities for undergraduate research.

ProgramName: Biology, Genetics and Biotechnology Concentration, B.S.
EnglishScore: Undergraduate applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by ONE of the following: TOEFL: 71 iBT (Internet-based) or 525 PBT (Paper-based), IELTS: 6.0, PTE Academic: 48, Duolingo English Test: 100, ELS Language Center: Level 112.
Requirements: First-time freshmen seeking admission to MTSU must submit an application for admission, a nonrefundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. An official ACT or SAT score is not required for admission but may be required for placement and some scholarship opportunities.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: MTSU's B.S. in Biology provides a comprehensive curriculum covering cell biology, genetics, ecology, evolution, and more. Students gain a foundational understanding of life sciences, preparing them for diverse careers in research, healthcare, education, and environmental fields.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be accomplished by submitting one of the following official scores: TOEFL iBT score of 61, IELTS score of 5.5, PTE score of 48, Duolingo English Test score of 95, or successful completion of ELS Level 109.
Requirements: To be considered for guaranteed admission, you must meet one of the following criteria: 3.0 GPA, OR; 2.7 GPA and 21 ACT composite (1060 SAT), OR; Graduate from a TN high school with a 2.7 GPA and completion of all 16 college prep courses
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The B.S. in Biology with Teacher Licensure program allows students to earn a bachelor's degree in Biology while simultaneously earning a teaching license in Secondary Education (grades 6-12). This program, offered in conjunction with the Department of Curriculum and Instruction, requires students to complete 120 credit hours in coursework, including 32 credit hours in Biology and 39 credit hours in education. Many students graduating with this degree will go on to teach biology in middle or high school. The program also serves as excellent preparation for graduate studies or for careers in related fields. Students interested in this program should contact the Biology department as early as possible to plan their curriculum.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $330/credit hour + fees; Out-of-State: $1,131/credit hour + fees

EnglishScore: Applicants from non-native English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be met by ONE of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL): Minimum 500 (PBT), 61 (iBT); International English Language Testing System (IELTS): Minimum 5.5; Pearson Test of English (PTE): Minimum 48; Duolingo: Minimum 95; Successful completion of the ELS Language Center's intensive program at Level 112.
Requirements:
To be eligible for assured admission to MTSU, you must meet one of the following:

High school GPA of 3.0 or higher
High school GPA of 2.7–2.99 AND 19 ACT or 990 SAT
High school GPA of 2.5–2.69 AND 21 ACT or 1060 SAT

Applicants who do not meet the assured admission criteria will be reviewed for admission on a holistic basis. Holistic review is a process where we look at the whole student, not just their GPA and test scores. Factors that may be considered include: high school course work, extracurricular activities, letters of recommendation, and essays.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Department of Chemistry at MTSU offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemistry with a concentration certified by the American Chemical Society (ACS). This concentration prepares students for careers in the chemical industry or for graduate study leading to master's or doctoral degrees in chemistry or related fields. The program meets the standards set forth by the ACS Committee on Professional Training, ensuring a rigorous and comprehensive education in the chemical sciences. Our curriculum emphasizes a strong foundation in all major areas of chemistry: analytical, biochemistry, inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry. Students gain hands-on experience through extensive laboratory work and research opportunities with faculty. The program focuses on developing critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills essential for success in scientific careers.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry with the ACS Certified Concentration is approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS) Committee on Professional Training. This certification signifies that the program meets rigorous national standards for undergraduate chemistry education.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English are required to submit official test scores for one of the following to demonstrate a satisfactory level of proficiency in the English language: TOEFL (71 iBT/525 PBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE academic (54), Duolingo (100), ELS (Level 112).
Requirements: In addition to the university’s general requirements, applicants for regular admission into the Master of Science program in Computer Science must have a 3.00 GPA or a 2.75 GPA and a preferred combined score of 300 on the verbal and quantitative sections of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE). A student must have an undergraduate major in computer science or a related area with a significant number of upper-division computer science courses including Data Structures and Assembly Language or Computer Organization. Any deficiencies must be completed before unconditional admission will be granted. Admission is competitive; not all applicants who meet the minimum requirements are admitted. Students who do not meet regular admission requirements may be considered for conditional admission. Please see the graduate catalog for details. The department must receive all of the following by the application deadline in order for an application to be considered.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Fees: TN Resident: $7,133/Semester; Non-TN Resident: $14,594/Semester (Based on 9 credit hours for Fall 2023/Spring 2024)
Description: MTSU's Master of Science (M.S.) in Computer Science program offers students the opportunity to conduct research and expand their knowledge in several advanced computer science areas. Students can choose between a thesis and non-thesis option, allowing for flexibility based on their career goals. The thesis option provides an in-depth research experience, ideal for those considering doctoral studies or research-oriented positions. The non-thesis option emphasizes coursework and practical applications, preparing students for immediate roles in industry. Faculty members are active in research, providing students with opportunities to work on cutting-edge projects in areas such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, cybersecurity, data science, and software engineering. The M.S. in Computer Science program is designed to provide students with the advanced knowledge, skills, and research experience necessary for successful careers in industry, government, or academia.
CostPerCredit: TN Resident: $738/credit hour; Non-TN Resident: $1,567/credit hour (for 2023-24, includes mandatory fees per credit hour)
CollegeApplicationFee: TN Resident: $7,133/Semester; Non-TN Resident: $14,594/Semester (Based on 9 credit hours for Fall 2023/Spring 2024)
MinimumGreScore: A minimum combined score of 290 on the verbal and quantitative sections and a minimum of 143 on the quantitative section.
ScholarshipAmount: Graduate Assistantship stipends range from $1,111.11 to $1,333.33 per month.
ScholarshipPercentage: Graduate Assistantships provide full tuition coverage.

EnglishScore: International undergraduate applicants must demonstrate English proficiency by one of the following: a minimum score of 525 on the paper-based test (PBT) or 71 on the internet-based test (iBT); a minimum score of 6.0 on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS); a minimum score of 58 on the Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic; a minimum score of 100 on the Duolingo English Test; completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: Applicants must meet one of the following criteria: 3.0 GPA OR Minimum 22 ACT composite (1020 SAT) OR 2.7 GPA and 19 ACT composite (980-1010 SAT). Test Optional: MTSU will not require an ACT or SAT score for admissions and scholarship consideration for applicants with a 3.0 GPA or higher. Required application materials include an official high school transcript and a non-refundable $25 application fee.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Fees: In-State: $9,658/year; Out-of-State: $27,418/year (2023-2024, includes tuition and mandatory fees for full-time students)
Description: Data Science is a rapidly emerging field centered on extracting knowledge and insights from structured and unstructured data. Data scientists use skills from statistics, computer science, and specific subject matter areas to analyze data and address complex problems. Our program provides a solid foundation in data science concepts, statistical methods, computational tools, and practical applications, preparing students for careers in this dynamic and growing field. This multidisciplinary degree program integrates coursework from the Departments of Computer Science and Mathematical Sciences and features a practical, hands-on capstone experience.

ProgramName: Engineering Technology, Computer Eng. Tech. B.S.
EnglishScore: All applicants must meet the English proficiency requirement. Accepted proofs include TOEFL (71 iBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE Academic (48), Duolingo (95), or completion of ELS Language Center's Level 112. Certain exemptions apply.
Requirements: MTSU practices a comprehensive review of all freshman applications. Primary consideration is given to the applicant's high school grade point average (GPA) in academic courses and any available ACT or SAT scores. For regular admission, you should have either a 3.0 GPA or a 2.7 GPA and a 19 ACT (or 990 SAT).
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering Technology program teaches students to integrate electrical engineering, computer science, and engineering technology to develop, design, test, and implement computer systems in modern applications. The program provides the graduate with the expertise to design, program, and maintain modern computer systems by utilizing the latest hardware and software tools. The curriculum includes areas in digital logic design, embedded systems, microcontrollers, computer architecture, data communication and networking, programming languages, and operating systems. Graduates of the program are able to apply the knowledge and skills necessary for successful careers in industry, research, and development. Typical positions include computer hardware engineer, embedded systems developer, network administrator, and computer systems analyst.
Accredidation: The Computer Engineering Technology program is accredited by the Engineering Technology Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

EnglishScore: As this is an undergraduate program, specific test scores like GRE/GMAT are not required. For international undergraduate applicants, English proficiency must be demonstrated. Accepted ways to demonstrate proficiency include a minimum TOEFL score of 61 (iBT) or 500 (PBT), a minimum IELTS score of 5.5, a minimum PTE Academic score of 48, a minimum Duolingo score of 95, or successful completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: Admission to MTSU is a separate process from applying to a major. To be admitted to this major, students must meet the general undergraduate admission requirements of the university.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: MTSU's Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree program in Environmental Sustainability and Technology prepares students for careers in the growing green economy. Students learn about environmental and energy systems, policy, and management issues related to energy production and conservation, pollution prevention, and remediation. This program includes a strong technical core with a focus on problem-solving, analytical skills, and hands-on laboratory and field experience through interdisciplinary instruction from faculty in Science, Engineering Technology, and other departments. The program focuses on how technologies can provide solutions to environmental problems and lead to a more sustainable future.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting one of the following: TOEFL score of 71 iBT (or 525 PBT), IELTS overall band score of 6.0, PTE Academic score of 52, Duolingo score of 100, or successful completion of ELS Level 112.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Geosciences program is designed to provide graduate students with advanced training in the diverse fields of geosciences. Students can choose a thesis or non-thesis option, tailored to their career aspirations. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research methodologies, and hands-on experience, preparing graduates for successful careers in academia, government, and industry. Students in the Geosciences, M.S. program will develop: Advanced understanding of geological processes, Earth systems, and environmental geosciences; Proficiency in data analysis, geospatial technologies, and field investigation techniques; The ability to design and conduct independent research, analyze complex data, and effectively communicate scientific findings; Critical thinking skills to address contemporary environmental and geological challenges.
ScholarshipAmount: $9,000 stipend for the academic year (for graduate assistantships)

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum Scores: TOEFL: 71 iBT / 525 PBT; IELTS: 6.0; PTE Academic: 54; Duolingo: 100; ELS Language Center: Completion of Level 112.
Requirements: Regular admission is granted to students with a 3.0+ GPA regardless of test scores. Students who do not meet the 3.0 GPA requirement may still be admitted with a qualifying test score: 3.50 - 4.00 GPA - Test Scores Not Required; 3.00 - 3.49 GPA - Test Scores Not Required; 2.99 GPA or below - Min 19 ACT or 990 SAT.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Mathematics, B.S. with a concentration in Advanced Mathematics is designed for students who wish to pursue a graduate degree in Mathematics or a related field, or to work in a position requiring strong mathematical skills. As an Advanced Mathematics concentration student, you will delve deeper into theoretical mathematics. You will master abstract algebra, real analysis, complex analysis, and geometry through a rigorous and comprehensive curriculum, allowing you to develop a robust understanding of advanced mathematical concepts. This program provides an excellent foundation for those interested in graduate studies in mathematics or related fields, such as theoretical physics or computer science, or for those seeking careers in research and development requiring advanced analytical and problem-solving skills.
ScholarshipAmount: Guaranteed scholarships range from $3,000 to $5,000 per year
ScholarshipPercentage: 84.5% of first-time, full-time undergraduate students received grant or scholarship aid in Fall 2023

EnglishScore: International applicants must provide proof of English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL (71 iBT / 525 PBT), IELTS (6.0), PTE Academic (48), Duolingo (100), or ELS (Level 112).
Requirements:
MTSU offers guaranteed admission to students who meet one of the following criteria:

1. 3.0 GPA
2. 2.7 GPA and 22 ACT (1100 SAT)

Beginning with the Fall 2021 semester, MTSU will not require an ACT or SAT score for admissions purposes for students with a 3.0 or higher high school GPA. The optional ACT writing score is not required for admission. Students who do not meet the 3.0 GPA requirement for test-optional admission can still be considered for admission with qualifying test scores and a 2.7 GPA or by holistic review.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences

ProgramName: Mathematics, Statistics and Data Analysis Concentration, B.S.
EnglishScore: Applicants from non-English speaking countries must demonstrate English proficiency. Options include: TOEFL (500 paper-based, 61 internet-based), IELTS (5.5 overall band score), PTE Academic (48), Duolingo English Test (95), or completion of ELS Language Center Level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the B.S. in Mathematics requires only admission to the University. To be considered for freshman admission, you must meet one of the following criteria: Standard Diploma and a 3.0 GPA or higher; Standard Diploma, a minimum 2.7 GPA, and a minimum 19 ACT (or 990 SAT); Standard Diploma, less than 2.7 GPA, minimum 21 ACT (or 1060 SAT). MTSU is currently test-optional; students may apply for admission without a test score.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Concentration: Mathematics, Statistics and Data Analysis Concentration
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Mathematics with a concentration in Statistics and Data Analysis is for students who want to develop strong theoretical knowledge of mathematics, especially as it applies to statistics, data analysis, and mathematical modeling. This program provides students with the critical thinking and problem-solving skills needed to pursue graduate degrees in mathematics, statistics, or data science, or to prepare them for careers in industry or government. Students completing this concentration will be well-prepared to sit for actuarial exams, earn teaching licenses (secondary level), or pursue employment in any field that requires analytical, quantitative, or computational problem-solving skills.

Requirements: The Accounting Minor requires 18 hours. A minimum of 50% of the hours in the minor must be taken at MTSU. Students majoring in Accounting may not minor in Accounting. Students minoring in Accounting may not minor in Business Administration.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: If you’re pursuing an undergraduate degree in a field other than Accounting, a minor in Accounting can help you understand the language of business – finances. No matter what your chosen field of study, an understanding of the balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement will benefit you. A basic understanding of accounting will assist you in managing your personal finances as well. An Accounting minor will provide you with a foundation in general business, financial accounting, managerial accounting, and accounting systems. For the minor, students must complete at least 15 semester hours in Accounting courses including 6 hours of upper-division courses.

Requirements:
A minor in Agriculture consists of 18 semester hours.

Required Courses (9 hours):

AGRI 1010 - Introduction to Agribusiness (3 hours)
AGRI 1020 - Introduction to Animal Science (3 hours)
AGRI 1030 - Introduction to Plant and Soil Science (3 hours)

Electives (9 hours):
Nine hours of agriculture electives selected with the agriculture advisor.
Department: School of Agriculture
Description: The Agricultural minor provides a pathway for students to learn about modern agriculture. It allows students who may not be pursuing an agricultural degree, but have an interest in agriculture, to have some general coursework to take and apply it to their existing major.

Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The minor in Anthropology allows students to gain a deeper understanding of human diversity in all its forms. From the evolution of our species and the study of nonhuman primates, to the development of complex societies, the anthropology minor can broaden your knowledge about the human experience. As an interdisciplinary field, Anthropology helps students to develop critical thinking, communication, and analytical skills that are highly valued in any career path. Students will be exposed to all four subfields of Anthropology (Cultural, Biological, Archaeological, and Linguistic) through core coursework and then have the opportunity to specialize through elective courses in areas that interest them. This program pairs well with any major, adding a valuable international and cross-cultural perspective to your degree.

Requirements: A minor in Business Administration requires a minimum of 18 hours. A minimum 2.00 GPA is required in the minor courses for graduation. Please see your advisor for the specific courses required for this minor.
Department: Jones College of Business
Description: The Business Administration minor at MTSU is for students in degree programs outside of the Jones College of Business. Through the Business Administration minor, students gain a solid foundation in the core principles of business while complementing their major field of study. Upon completion of the minor, students will have a well-rounded understanding of how businesses operate. Required courses: MGT 3610, MKT 3820, FIN 3010 or FIN 3600 (not both), BDA 2610, ECON 2420 or ECON 2410 (not both).

Requirements:
Students wishing to pursue a minor in Business Analytics must meet the following requirements:
Minimum 2.0 GPA
Must consult with a Business Analytics Minor advisor prior to or at the time of declaring the minor.
Must file an 'Intent to Minor' form with the Information Systems and Analytics Departmental Office, BAS N421.
Must complete a minimum of 6 hours in the minor at MTSU.
Must complete prerequisites before enrolling in any course. Check catalog for prerequisites.
Must earn a grade of 'C' (2.0) or better in all minor courses.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Business Analytics Minor is designed to provide business students with the knowledge and skills necessary to understand and apply analytical techniques to solve complex business problems. This minor will provide students with the ability to interpret data, create data visualizations, develop statistical models, and apply machine learning algorithms to improve decision making within an organization.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $398 per credit hour; Out-of-State: $1094 per credit hour (2024-25 rates)
ScholarshipAmount: Guaranteed freshman scholarships range from $2,000 to $8,000 per year

Requirements: This minor is open to all students.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Fees: In-State: $4,992/semester; Out-of-State: $15,480/semester (for 2024-2025). A Business Course Fee of $100 per credit hour also applies.
Description: MTSU's Business Law minor offers students a general knowledge of the legal environment in which businesses operate and an understanding of specific substantive areas of the law. The minor focuses on the legal concepts associated with the operation of a business enterprise and provides an overview of legal areas that have become increasingly critical to entrepreneurs and managers. It is especially useful for students interested in attending law school and those seeking positions in business law, human resource management, real estate, and finance. The minor consists of 15 credit hours of required coursework.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $416.50/credit hour; Out-of-State: $1290.50/credit hour (for 2024-2025). An additional $100/credit hour Business Course Fee applies to all business courses.
CollegeApplicationFee: In-State: $4,992/semester; Out-of-State: $15,480/semester (for 2024-2025). A Business Course Fee of $100 per credit hour also applies.
ScholarshipAmount: $3,500 to $8,000 per year for guaranteed freshman scholarships.

Requirements:
A minor in Communication consists of 18 semester hours.

Required Courses (6 hours)
* COMM 2200 - Fundamentals of Communication Credit Hours: 3
* COMM 3560 - Interpersonal Communication Credit Hours: 3

Electives (12 hours)
* Twelve hours selected from any COMM courses numbered 3000-4999.
Department: College of Media and Entertainment
Description: Communication is a fundamental skill essential for success in all aspects of life—personal, professional, and civic. The Communication minor is designed for students from any major who wish to enhance their communication skills, critical thinking, and understanding of human interaction. The curriculum provides students with a broad understanding of communication theories and practices. Students will develop practical skills in areas such as public speaking, interpersonal communication, organizational communication, and intercultural communication. An understanding of communication processes and effective communication strategies is highly valued by employers across various industries. This minor is an excellent complement to any major, providing a valuable skill set that will enhance your career prospects and personal development.

Requirements:
Students seeking a minor in criminal investigation must complete 18 semester hours from the list below.

Required Courses (6 hours)
CJUS 3010 - Criminal Investigation Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 3440 - Criminal Evidence and Procedure Credit Hours: 3

Electives (12 hours)
Twelve hours selected from the following:
CJUS 3020 - Homicide Investigation Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 3350 - Interviewing and Interrogation Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 3355 - Police and Community Relations Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 3550 - Cybercrime Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4010 - Crime Scene Investigation Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4100 - Arson Investigation Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4170 - White Collar Crime Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4460 - Computer Forensics Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4500 - Terrorism Credit Hours: 3
CJUS 4570 - The Intelligence Process Credit Hours: 3
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Criminal Investigation minor provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills necessary to pursue a career as a criminal investigator. This minor offers a comprehensive curriculum that covers various aspects of criminal investigations, including investigative techniques, forensic science principles, evidence collection and preservation, interview and interrogation strategies, and legal considerations. Students will learn about the different stages of an investigation, from initial response to case presentation in court. Through a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical applications, students will develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills essential for effective criminal investigation. The minor emphasizes ethical considerations and professionalism in the field, preparing students to uphold justice and contribute to public safety.

Requirements:
A minor in Criminal Justice Administration consists of 18 semester hours.

Required courses (12 hours)

CJA 1100 - Introduction to Criminal Justice
CJA 2100 - Criminology
CJA 2300 - Police and Society
CJA 2700 - The Adjudication Process

Six hours of CJA electives from upper-division courses.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The minor in Criminal Justice Administration is designed to provide students with an understanding of the criminal justice system as an area of scholarly study and professional practice. It is particularly relevant for students interested in a career in criminal justice agencies or those whose major field of study would be complemented by such a background.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to full tuition and fees

Requirements: A minor in Cultural Geography consists of a minimum of 15 semester hours. A grade of "C" or better is required in each course counted toward the minor.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Cultural Geography minor allows students to apply a spatial perspective to human activities. You will study population, religions, politics, economic development, and cultural landscapes from a geographic perspective. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers in city and regional planning, tourism, international business, and intelligence, or for further graduate study in geography. In this minor, students will acquire: (1) skills to understand and analyze spatial patterns and processes, (2) the ability to interpret and create maps, (3) knowledge of cultural phenomena, and (4) the ability to think critically about spatial issues.

ProgramName: Driver and Traffic Safety Education Minor
Requirements: Students must have a 2.75 GPA. See advisor for more information.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Driver and Traffic Safety Education Minor provides students with the academic and practical knowledge required to teach driver education. The curriculum includes courses in driver and traffic safety, methods of teaching driver education, and practical experience in teaching driver education. Graduates of this program are prepared to teach driver education in high schools and other educational settings.

Requirements: A minor in Economics consists of 15 semester hours.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: An undergraduate Minor in Economics consists of 18 credit hours and is available to all students except those majoring in Economics and those with a double major in Economics. An undergraduate Minor in Economics provides students with a foundational understanding of economic principles and how they can be applied to real-world situations. It complements a variety of majors by enhancing analytical and critical thinking skills, preparing students for diverse careers in business, finance, government, and law. It demonstrates a commitment to understanding market dynamics, policy impacts, and global economic trends, making graduates more competitive in the job market.
CostPerCredit: In-state: $448.50 per credit hour; Out-of-state: $1201.50 per credit hour

Requirements:
A minor in Economics/Finance requires a minimum of 15 semester hours. A grade of "C" or better is required in each course to be counted toward the minor.

Required Courses (6 hours)

ECON 2410 - Principles of Economics, Macroeconomics

FIN 3010 - Principles of Financial Management

Plus nine hours of upper-division Economics (ECON) and/or Finance (FIN) electives.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Fees: In-state: $9,934/year; Out-of-state: $31,126/year (based on 15 credits per semester for 2024-2025)
Description: The Economics/Finance minor is designed to provide students with foundational knowledge in economics and finance, which can complement a wide range of majors. The minor emphasizes practical application and critical thinking in areas such as financial markets, economic analysis, and investment principles. Students will develop skills essential for understanding global economic trends, making informed financial decisions, and preparing for careers in business, finance, and related fields.

Requirements:
A minor in Engineering Technology requires 18 semester hours. ET 1310 or consent of instructor is a prerequisite for all other ET courses.

Required Courses (9 hours)
ET 1310 - Manufacturing Processes credit: 3
ET 2310 - Manufacturing and Materials Technology credit: 3
ET 3610 - Industrial Controls credit: 3

Electives (9 hours)
Nine hours of electives chosen with an advisor from any 3000- or 4000-level ET courses.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Fees: $9,872/Year (based on full-time, in-state undergraduate tuition and mandatory fees for 2023-2024)
Description: The Engineering Technology Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge and skills in engineering technology. This minor complements various majors, offering a practical understanding of design, development, and implementation processes in technological systems. Students will engage with topics such as drafting, manufacturing processes, quality assurance, and project management. This minor is ideal for students seeking to broaden their technical expertise and enhance their career opportunities in fields requiring applied engineering skills.

Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: In this minor, students will discover the enduring power of language and literature. Whether through the study of diverse texts, creative writing, or rhetoric and writing, the English minor helps students develop critical thinking and communication skills essential for success in any career path. From analyzing classic works to crafting compelling narratives, students in this program will learn to appreciate the nuances of human expression and hone their abilities to interpret, create, and communicate effectively in a variety of contexts.

Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: An interdisciplinary minor that provides students with a broad understanding of the physical and biological processes that govern the natural world, the role of humans in modifying these processes, and the scientific methods used to analyze and address environmental problems. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor their coursework to their interests in natural science, social science, or policy-related issues relevant to the environment.
ScholarshipAmount: Guaranteed scholarships range from $3,500 to $5,000 per year

Requirements:
A minor in Finance consists of 15 semester hours.

Required Courses (9 hours)

FIN 3010 - Principles of Corporate Finance Credits: 3
FIN 3040 - Principles of Real Estate Credits: 3
FIN 3050 - Principles of Insurance Credits: 3

Electives (6 hours)

Select two courses from the following:

FIN 3000 - Personal Finance Credits: 3
FIN 3210 - Investments Credits: 3
FIN 3810 - Financial Institutions Credits: 3
FIN 4310 - International Finance Credits: 3
FIN 4450 - Derivatives Credits: 3
FIN 4550 - Bank Management Credits: 3
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Finance Minor is intended for students who desire to broaden their knowledge in finance, but who are not finance majors. The Finance Minor will provide students with the basic knowledge of financial markets and financial management. Students will learn how to make wise decisions regarding individual and corporate assets through an understanding of financial statements, time value of money, capital markets, and financial institutions. A minor in Finance will benefit students pursuing a variety of majors by adding a practical understanding of money and financial decision-making in personal and professional contexts.
Accredidation: Jennings A. Jones College of Business, which houses the Economics and Finance Department, is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

Requirements:
Required Courses (18 hours)

* HCAD 3200 - The U.S. Healthcare System 3 credit hours
* HCAD 3230 - Healthcare Quality 3 credit hours
* HCAD 3250 - Healthcare Information Systems 3 credit hours
* HCAD 4210 - Healthcare Economics 3 credit hours
* HCAD 4240 - Healthcare Policy 3 credit hours
* HCAD 4270 - Healthcare Law and Ethics 3 credit hours
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Healthcare Administration Minor provides students with knowledge and skills for entry-level administrative positions in a variety of healthcare settings. This minor is open to all students at MTSU. Students desiring to declare a minor in Healthcare Administration should contact the Department of Health and Human Performance for additional advising information.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $5,000/year for guaranteed freshman scholarships

Requirements: A minor in History requires 18 hours. A minimum of 9 hours must be upper division. Twelve (12) hours must be taken at MTSU. See department for approved courses.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: A minor in History consists of 18 semester hours of History courses. No more than 6 semester hours of credit may be transferred from another institution. No more than 3 semester hours of History credit may be earned by special examination or by portfolio. No more than 6 semester hours may be 1000-level courses. A grade of C- or better is required in all courses counted toward the minor. The minor can be earned either through the traditional face-to-face classroom setting or entirely online.
CostPerCredit: $327/credit hour (In-State undergraduate maintenance fee for 2023-24, additional fees apply)

Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Homeland Security Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for careers in homeland security and related fields. It provides a broad overview of the various threats facing the nation, as well as the strategies and policies in place to address them. The minor emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute to the safety and security of communities at local, state, and national levels.

Requirements: A minor in Human Sciences requires a minimum of 18 semester hours. Courses must be selected from three of the following areas: Family and Consumer Sciences (FCS) education, interior design (ID), merchandising (MERCH), nutrition and food science (NFS), or textiles, merchandising, and design (TXMD).
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Human Sciences minor provides students with the opportunity to gain fundamental knowledge in subject matter that supports the human condition. The minor is offered to provide students with a general background in fields related to human needs, such as individuals, families, and communities. Students will gain knowledge related to family and consumer sciences, nutrition, housing, textiles, and human development.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $6,000 per year for guaranteed scholarships

Requirements: To complete a minor in Information Systems, a student must complete 15 semester hours from the following. At least 9 hours of the minor must be from courses numbered 3000 or above.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: Information systems are the foundation of business, and an information systems minor can provide students with knowledge and skills to understand the role of information systems within an organization. Students will explore how information systems are used to solve business problems, how they are managed, and how they contribute to an organization's overall success. Courses cover topics such as database management, business intelligence, systems analysis and design, and cybersecurity.

Requirements: The Journalism Minor requires 18 hours. A grade of C or better is required in each course. A maximum of 6 hours in the minor may be taken in the major.
Department: College of Media and Entertainment
Description: The minor in Journalism will expose students to skills in reporting, writing, editing, and ethics that will prepare them for a variety of careers in the media industry. Students will study the history of journalism and its role in society, and learn best practices for gathering, evaluating, and presenting information. The minor will complement any major, helping students develop critical thinking and communication skills essential for success in today's complex world.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts for guaranteed scholarships range from $2,000 to $8,000 per year.

Requirements: A minor in Leisure and Sport Management requires a GPA of at least 2.25. The Leisure and Sport Management minor is a total of 18 hours. Required courses (9 hours): LSM 3210 - Program Planning in Leisure and Sport Management; LSM 3290 - Facility Planning in Leisure and Sport Management; LSM 4210 - Legal Issues in Leisure and Sport Management. Electives (9 hours): Students select nine (9) hours of upper division Leisure and Sport Management courses.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Fees: In-state: $10,114/year; Out-of-state: $29,578/year (based on 12+ credit hours per semester for Fall 2024-Spring 2025)
Description: The Leisure & Sport Management (LSM) minor is designed to develop knowledge and skills to provide for a wide variety of recreation, sport, leisure, and entertainment opportunities within diverse sectors of the leisure industry. This minor will expand students’ understanding of the field and prepare them for employment or graduate study in areas such as: community recreation, sport and athletics, outdoor recreation, event management, resort and commercial recreation, youth-serving organizations, tourism, campus recreation, and military recreation. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor course selection to meet their individual interests and career goals. Because of the growing interest in health and well-being, the leisure and sport industry continues to expand as individuals and groups seek positive leisure experiences.
CostPerCredit: In-state: $565/credit hour; Out-of-state: $1,341/credit hour (based on Fall 2024-Spring 2025 non-guaranteed rates)
CollegeApplicationFee: In-state: $10,114/year; Out-of-state: $29,578/year (based on 12+ credit hours per semester for Fall 2024-Spring 2025)
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $6,000 per year for guaranteed freshman scholarships

Requirements:
A minor in Management requires 18 hours.

Required Courses (9 hours)
MGMT 3610 - Principles of Management and Organizational Behavior (3 credit hours)
MGMT 3620 - Supply Chain Operations (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4680 - Strategic Management (3 credit hours)

Electives (9 hours)
Select 9 hours from the following:

BLAW 3430 - Commercial Law (3 credit hours)
ENTR 3100 - Introduction to Entrepreneurship (3 credit hours)
MGMT 3080 - Business and Society (3 credit hours)
MGMT 3710 - Human Resource Management (3 credit hours)
MGMT 3820 - International Management (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4100 - Leadership and Motivation (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4200 - Management of Not-for-Profit Organizations (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4640 - Project Management (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4710 - Staffing Organizations (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4720 - Training and Development (3 credit hours)
MGMT 4730 - Compensation and Benefits (3 credit hours)
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Fees: In-State: $9,988/year; Out-of-State: $29,956/year (based on 2024-2025 rates for full-time undergraduates)
Description: The minor in Management is for students desiring an understanding of management concepts related to the business, private, or public sectors. Students will learn how organizations function, how managers motivate people, how to manage human resources, how to develop strategies to compete, and how to operate effectively and efficiently in a global economy. It is a good choice for those who are in a non-business major or those who wish to complement a business major.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $413/credit hour; Out-of-State: $1,245/credit hour (based on 2024-2025 rates)
CollegeApplicationFee: In-State: $9,988/year; Out-of-State: $29,956/year (based on 2024-2025 rates for full-time undergraduates)
ScholarshipPercentage: 86% of beginning full-time freshmen receive grants or scholarships

Requirements: The requirements for a minor in marketing are MKT 3820 Principles of Marketing and 15 additional upper-division (3000-4000 level) MKT hours. A grade of 'C' or better is required in all minor courses. At least 6 semester hours of the minor must be taken at MTSU. A minor is declared on the 'major/minor change' form available in your college advising center, as well as on PipelineMT.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: A minor in Marketing can be a valuable addition to your academic portfolio regardless of your major. The minor provides a basic understanding of marketing principles and is an excellent complement to many majors such as Entrepreneurship, Professional Selling, Business Administration, Computer Information Systems, Fashion Merchandising, Graphic Design, Communication Studies, and Journalism, to name a few. Marketing courses will equip you with knowledge and skills relevant to various careers, including advertising, brand management, digital marketing, market research, and sales. It can also serve as a foundational step toward pursuing a master's degree in marketing or an MBA. The Department of Marketing offers a diverse selection of courses, allowing you to tailor your minor to align with your interests and career goals. Some of these course topics include digital marketing, advertising, international marketing, and social media marketing. The Marketing minor is open to all majors except Marketing majors (who already get more marketing content than the minor offers). To earn a minor in Marketing, you must complete 18 semester hours (6 courses) of Marketing (MKT) courses with at least 9 of the 18 hours completed at MTSU. Students must earn a grade of “C-” or better in all courses taken to complete the minor.
CostPerCredit: $441.50 per credit hour for in-state undergraduates (Fall 2024 rate)

Requirements: Minor in Mass Communication is open to all university students. Students minoring in Mass Communication are not required to complete a formal admission process for the College of Media and Entertainment.
Department: College of Media and Entertainment
Description: A minor in Mass Communication will complement most any major at MTSU. If you desire to develop a broad understanding of the role and influence of mass media in society, along with basic skills to produce content or tell stories, then this minor is for you. This minor is comprised of 18 credit hours and can be combined with any major outside of the College of Media and Entertainment. If you are majoring in a program within the College of Media and Entertainment, you should seek advisement regarding the courses you may take to satisfy requirements of the minor.

Requirements: A minor in Nutrition and Food Science requires a minimum of 18 semester hours. A minimum grade of C is required in all minor courses.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: The Nutrition and Food Science minor at MTSU provides students with a foundational understanding of nutrition principles and food science concepts. This minor is an excellent complement to a variety of majors, including those in health sciences, exercise science, biology, chemistry, and hospitality. Students will learn about human nutrition, food preparation, food safety, and the role of food in health and disease. The curriculum emphasizes both the scientific aspects of food and nutrition and their practical applications. This minor is designed to enhance students' career readiness in fields related to health, wellness, food industry, and consumer education.

Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: A minor in political science requires 15 credit hours of Political Science (POS) courses. The minor will provide students with a basic understanding of government and politics in the United States and around the world, as well as the major subfields of political science. It is an excellent complement to several majors at MTSU, including Criminal Justice Administration, Economics, History, Global Studies, and Social Work.
ScholarshipAmount: $2,000 - $6,000 per year; Full-tuition scholarships also available

Requirements: Registration is open to all individuals and teams.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: Our Professional Selling Certificate program is a non-credit executive education program offered to the general public, designed to help individuals acquire the skills and confidence necessary to excel in a dynamic sales environment. Whether you are new to sales, a seasoned professional looking to refine your techniques, or an entrepreneur aiming to boost your business, this certificate will equip you with practical strategies and insights for immediate impact. Our program blends theoretical knowledge with real-world applications, ensuring a comprehensive learning experience. In this program, participants will gain an understanding of: The fundamentals of the sales process, including prospecting, lead generation, and client relationship management. Effective communication and negotiation strategies tailored for sales interactions. How to identify customer needs and present solutions that resonate. Building long-term client relationships and fostering customer loyalty. Utilizing technology and data analytics to enhance sales performance. Ethical considerations and professional conduct in sales.

Requirements: A minor in Psychology consists of 18 hours. A grade of C or better is required in all psychology courses used for the minor. Students must complete PSY 1410 as a prerequisite to all other psychology courses. This course will not count toward the minor.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Fees: In-State: $5,052/Semester, Out-of-State: $14,796/Semester (for full-time undergraduates, Fall 2024 - Spring 2025)
Description: By adding a Psychology minor, students gain valuable knowledge about human behavior, cognition, and emotion that can complement any major. This minor enhances critical thinking, research skills, and an understanding of psychological principles, making graduates more versatile and appealing to a wide range of employers or for further academic pursuits.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $421/credit hour, Out-of-State: $1,233/credit hour (for undergraduates, Fall 2024 - Spring 2025)

Requirements: A minor in Public Health requires 18 hours. The following courses are required (12 hours): HED 2210, HED 3300, HED 3330, HED 3400. Students must choose 6 hours of electives from the following courses: HED 3320, HED 3340, HED 4200, HED 4350, HED 4650, HED 4670, HED 4700. In addition, students are encouraged to consider the following courses as possible University electives: BIOL 1030/BIOL 1031; ECON 2410; GEOG 2000; NFS 1240; PSY 1410; SOC 1010, SOC 2010. Students who minor in Public Health are advised through the Department of Health and Human Performance.
Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: Public Health is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life and promoting health through the organized efforts and informed choices of society, organizations, public and private communities and individuals. Public health addresses human health at the population level, and a minor in Public Health complements any major because every career field directly or indirectly impacts the health of its workers, clients, or communities.
CostPerCredit: $438 per credit hour (in-state); $1,280 per credit hour (out-of-state)
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with guaranteed freshman awards ranging from $2,000 to $6,000 per year.

Requirements: The Public Relations minor requires 18 hours. Required courses (12 hours): JOUR 2710; PR 3350, 3450, 4750. Choose two courses from the following (6 hours): PR 3300, 3550, 4400, 4700; JOUR 3080, 3120, 3130, 3420, 3430, 3500, 3560, 4100, 4670; RIM 3600.
Department: School of Journalism and Strategic Media
Description: The Public Relations minor requires 18 hours. These hours include three core classes plus three additional classes from a list of approved courses. The PR minor provides students with a solid foundation in the concepts and practices of public relations, preparing them for a variety of entry-level positions in the field. Students learn to research, plan, implement, and evaluate public relations campaigns, as well as develop strong written and oral communication skills.

Requirements: Students pursuing a minor in Medieval Studies must complete 18 semester hours, 9 of which must be upper-division. Courses from at least three different departments must be included. A list of courses is available from the program coordinator. Students are encouraged to pursue an interdisciplinary and chronological balance in their coursework for the minor.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Medieval Studies minor introduces students to the culture, history, and literature of medieval Europe (c. 500-1500 C.E.). Students will gain familiarity with the period through a series of core courses and electives, developing a deeper understanding of the foundations of Western civilization. Medieval Studies combines the traditional disciplines of history and English with art, philosophy, religious studies, and foreign languages. Students pursuing the minor will encounter the history, thought, culture, and literature of this fascinating period and learn more about the Middle Ages in Europe and beyond.

Requirements: In order to declare a minor in Musical Theatre Performance, students must audition for the Department of Theatre and Dance. Audition requirements: Prepare a one-minute monologue from a published play. Prepare a one-minute song from the musical theatre repertoire. Bring your sheet music in the proper key. An accompanist will be provided. Be prepared for a short dance combination taught by our faculty. Bring a recent photograph (headshot preferred) which will not be returned.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Department of Theatre and Dance offers a minor in Musical Theatre Performance. The Musical Theatre Minor provides students interested in musical theatre a focused course of study that combines acting, dance, and music. This minor is open to all students, regardless of major. It is especially suitable for Theatre majors with an emphasis in performance, Dance majors, and Music majors with an emphasis in voice or instrumental performance.

Requirements: A minor in Great Books requires 18 hours. Choose one of the following: ENGL 2020 - Themes in Literature and Culture (3 credit hours) or HUM 2610 - Foreign Literature in Translation (3 credit hours). The remaining 15 hours will be selected from the approved list of courses below, with at least 9 hours at the 3000-4000 level.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Great Books Minor provides students with the opportunity to engage with the enduring questions raised in some of the most influential works of literature, philosophy, history, and science. Students will explore a wide range of texts, from ancient epics to modern novels, delving into fundamental themes such as justice, truth, beauty, and the human condition. The minor emphasizes critical thinking, close reading, and robust discussion, fostering a deeper understanding of intellectual traditions and their continued relevance. Through rigorous engagement with these foundational texts, students will enhance their analytical and communication skills, preparing them for diverse academic and professional pursuits.

Requirements: The African-American Studies minor consists of 18 semester hours. Required course: AAS 2100 - Introduction to African-American Studies (3 credit hours). Fifteen (15) additional semester hours must be chosen from the list of approved courses.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The African American Studies minor offers an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the history, culture, and social experiences of people of African descent, particularly in the United States. This program encourages students to critically engage with diverse perspectives and research methodologies. Through coursework in various fields such as history, literature, sociology, political science, and music, students will explore the significant contributions of African Americans, examine issues of race and identity, and analyze dynamics of power, social justice, and resistance. The minor enhances critical thinking, research skills, and cultural competency, preparing students for diverse careers and engaged citizenship.

Requirements: The Entrepreneurship minor is open to all students on campus.
Department: Jennings A. Jones College of Business
Description: The Entrepreneurship Minor provides students with the critical skills and knowledge needed to launch, manage, and grow new ventures successfully. It focuses on developing an entrepreneurial mindset, understanding market opportunities, securing funding, and creating sustainable business models. This minor is suitable for students across all disciplines who aspire to become entrepreneurs, innovators, or leaders in established organizations.

Requirements: The Electronics Minor requires 15 hours of coursework. All courses for the minor must have a minimum grade of C-. Required courses (9 hours): ET 2310 - DC Circuits, ET 3330 - AC Circuits, ET 3620 - Digital Circuits. Approved electives (6 hours) - Select two courses from: ET 3350 - Electronic Devices, ET 3630 - Microcontroller Systems, ET 3920 - Industrial Controls and PLC, ET 4370 - Electronics Communications, ET 4640 - Mechatronics Interfacing.
Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: This minor allows students to apply scientific and engineering principles to the research, design, development, construction, installation, maintenance, and operation of electrical and electronic systems and their components. This minor is typically pursued by students majoring in other technical areas (e.g., Computer Science, Engineering Technology, Mechatronics, Physics, etc.) but is available to all students. The minor provides a basic foundation in electronics applicable to a variety of careers. The minor requires 18 hours including: ET 1600; ET 2610; ET 2660; and 9 hours of approved ET electives from 3000/4000 level.

Department: College of Basic and Applied Sciences
Description: The Engineering Systems minor is intended to provide fundamental knowledge and skills needed to understand and manage complex systems. The minor will cover topics such as system design, analysis, optimization, and control, as well as the use of various tools and techniques to model, simulate, and evaluate system performance. Students who complete the Engineering Systems minor will be well-prepared to pursue careers in a variety of fields, including aerospace, automotive, manufacturing, and telecommunications.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Students may demonstrate proficiency by ONE of the following: TOEFL score of 525 (paper-based), 195 (computer-based), or 71 (Internet-based); IELTS score of 6.0; PTE academic score of 53; Duolingo score of 100; GTEC CBT score of 1070; ELS Language Center Level 112; Completion of the equivalent to English 1010 and 1020 at an accredited U.S. college or university with a grade of 'C' or better; Graduation from a U.S. high school with one year of attendance; Citizenship of a country on the English Speaking Countries list.
Requirements: To be guaranteed admission, an applicant must have a 3.0 high school GPA or an ACT composite of 22 (SAT 1100) or a 2.7 high school GPA and an ACT composite of 20 (SAT 1020). Applicants who do not meet guaranteed admission requirements will be considered for conditional admission.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: Middle Tennessee State University is adding a new major: Africana Studies. Beginning in fall 2021, students will be able to pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies, a comprehensive interdisciplinary program designed to examine the histories, cultures, and intellectual traditions of people of African descent across Africa and the diaspora. The degree examines the histories, cultures and intellectual traditions of people of African descent across Africa and the diaspora. Students will develop strong analytical and communication skills, as well as cultural competency necessary to thrive in an increasingly diverse and globalized world. The new major will teach students to think critically, communicate effectively, analyze issues, and provide historical and contemporary context for addressing questions of race, identity, culture and power within local, national and global communities. It prepares graduates for a variety of careers in social work, law, education, journalism, government, public policy and non-profit organizations. It will also serve as strong preparation for graduate studies.

EnglishScore: Students from non-English speaking countries must submit one of the following to demonstrate English proficiency. TOEFL: 525 (paper-based), 195 (computer-based), or 71 (Internet-based) or higher. IELTS: 6.0 or higher. PTE: 54 or higher. Duolingo: 100 or higher. ELS: Completion of ELS Level 112.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: Africana Studies is an interdisciplinary program that brings together the study of African American, African, and Caribbean peoples, cultures, and societies from a global perspective. The curriculum is designed to equip students with critical analytical and research skills applicable to diverse careers. Students in the Africana Studies major will have the opportunity to delve into various aspects of the Black experience, including history, literature, politics, economics, sociology, and culture. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches, encouraging students to explore the complexities of race, identity, power, and social justice.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies (e.g., guaranteed awards from $1,500 to $8,000 per year)

Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The African Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the histories, cultures, societies, economies, and politics of Africa and its diaspora. Students will explore diverse perspectives on African experiences, challenge stereotypes, and develop critical thinking skills necessary for engaging with complex global issues. The minor aims to foster cross-cultural understanding, prepare students for careers in fields with international dimensions, and equip them with a global perspective invaluable in an interconnected world.

Requirements: A minor in Asian Studies requires 18 hours. Nine (9) hours must be at the upper-division level. No more than six (6) hours may be from the student's major.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: This minor prepares students for global citizenship and careers in government, education, law, business, and nonprofit organizations working in or with Asian countries. The minor focuses on the languages, cultures, histories, and political and economic systems of Asian societies. The curriculum requires 18 hours. These hours must include a minimum of 6 hours in Asian Studies (ASIA) courses, 3 hours in Asian language courses (Chinese, Japanese, or Arabic), and 9 hours of electives chosen from an approved list of courses. At least 9 hours must be at the 3000–4000 level. Students must maintain a minimum 2.0 GPA in all minor courses. The Asian Studies minor can be paired with any major.
ScholarshipAmount: Guaranteed freshman scholarships range from $2,000 to $5,000 per year.

Department: College of Behavioral and Health Sciences
Description: This minor is designed for students who desire to enhance their understanding of the scientific method as it applies to the social, behavioral, and health sciences. The Behavioral Research minor would be appropriate for any student interested in: (a) graduate education in a social, behavioral, or health science; (b) careers in research (e.g., as a research assistant); or (c) applying research skills to problems in community organizations, business, or government. The minor is highly customizable to meet a student’s specific interests and needs.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $7,000 per year for top academic awards like the Presidential Scholarship.

Requirements: The minor requires 18 hours. A grade of C or better is required in each course counted toward the minor.
Department: College of Liberal Arts
Description: The Classical Studies minor provides students with the opportunity to take courses in Latin and Greek language as well as ancient history, literature, philosophy, and mythology. The minor gives students the chance to explore the foundations of Western civilization and learn about topics like Roman generals, Greek heroes, and classical architecture. It is an excellent complement to many majors, including English, History, Philosophy, Political Science, and Foreign Languages. Students pursuing a minor in Classical Studies should complete 15 hours of coursework in subjects related to classical antiquity. Students should work with their advisors to select courses that best fit their interests and complement their major.
CostPerCredit: TN Resident: $423/credit hour; Non-TN Resident: $1102/credit hour
